# API Documentation [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#api-documentation "Link to this heading")

## Overview [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#overview "Link to this heading")

The AsyncSSH API is modeled after the new Python `asyncio` framework, with
a [`create_connection()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.create_connection "asyncssh.create_connection") coroutine to create an SSH client and a
[`create_server()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.create_server "asyncssh.create_server") coroutine to create an SSH server. Like the
`asyncio` framework, these calls take a parameter of a factory which
creates protocol objects to manage the connections once they are open.
For AsyncSSH, [`create_connection()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.create_connection "asyncssh.create_connection") should be passed a `client_factory`
which returns objects derived from [`SSHClient`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClient "asyncssh.SSHClient") and [`create_server()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.create_server "asyncssh.create_server")
should be passed a `server_factory` which returns objects derived from
[`SSHServer`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServer "asyncssh.SSHServer"). In addition, each connection will have an associated
[`SSHClientConnection`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection") or [`SSHServerConnection`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerConnection "asyncssh.SSHServerConnection") object passed
to the protocol objects which can be used to perform actions on the connection.

For client connections, authentication can be performed by passing in a
username and password or SSH keys as arguments to [`create_connection()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.create_connection "asyncssh.create_connection")
or by implementing handler methods on the [`SSHClient`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClient "asyncssh.SSHClient") object which
return credentials when the server requests them. If no credentials are
provided, AsyncSSH automatically attempts to send the username of the
local user and the keys found in their `.ssh` subdirectory. A list of
expected server host keys can also be specified, with AsyncSSH defaulting
to looking for matching lines in the user’s `.ssh/known_hosts` file.

For server connections, handlers can be implemented on the [`SSHServer`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServer "asyncssh.SSHServer")
object to return which authentication methods are supported and to validate
credentials provided by clients.

Once an SSH client connection is established and authentication is successful,
multiple simultaneous channels can be opened on it. This is accomplished
calling methods such as [`create_session()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.create_session "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.create_session"), [`create_connection()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.create_connection "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.create_connection"), [`create_unix_connection()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.create_unix_connection "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.create_unix_connection"), [`create_tun()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.create_tun "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.create_tun"), and [`create_tap()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.create_tap "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.create_tap") on the [`SSHClientConnection`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection") object.
The client can also set up listeners on remote TCP ports and UNIX domain
sockets by calling [`create_server()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.create_server "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.create_server")
and [`create_unix_server()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.create_unix_server "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.create_unix_server").
All of these methods take `session_factory` arguments that return
[`SSHClientSession`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientSession "asyncssh.SSHClientSession"), [`SSHTCPSession`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHTCPSession "asyncssh.SSHTCPSession"), or [`SSHUNIXSession`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHUNIXSession "asyncssh.SSHUNIXSession")
objects used to manage the channels once they are open. Alternately, channels
can be opened using [`open_session()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.open_session "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.open_session"),
[`open_connection()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.open_connection "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.open_connection"),
[`open_unix_connection()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.open_unix_connection "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.open_unix_connection"),
[`open_tun()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.open_tun "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.open_tun"), or
[`open_tap()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.open_tap "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.open_tap"), which return
[`SSHReader`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHReader "asyncssh.SSHReader") and [`SSHWriter`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHWriter "asyncssh.SSHWriter") objects that can be used to
perform I/O on the channel. The methods [`start_server()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.start_server "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.start_server") and [`start_unix_server()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.start_unix_server "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.start_unix_server") can be used to set up listeners on
remote TCP ports or UNIX domain sockets and get back these [`SSHReader`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHReader "asyncssh.SSHReader")
and [`SSHWriter`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHWriter "asyncssh.SSHWriter") objects in a callback when new connections are opened.

SSH client sessions can also be opened by calling [`create_process()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.create_process "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.create_process"). This returns a [`SSHClientProcess`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientProcess "asyncssh.SSHClientProcess")
object which has members `stdin`, `stdout`, and `stderr` which are
[`SSHReader`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHReader "asyncssh.SSHReader") and [`SSHWriter`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHWriter "asyncssh.SSHWriter") objects. This API also makes
it very easy to redirect input and output from the remote process to local
files, pipes, sockets, or other [`SSHReader`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHReader "asyncssh.SSHReader") and [`SSHWriter`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHWriter "asyncssh.SSHWriter")
objects. In cases where you just want to run a remote process to completion
and get back an object containing captured output and exit status, the
[`run()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.run "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.run") method can be used. It returns an
[`SSHCompletedProcess`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHCompletedProcess "asyncssh.SSHCompletedProcess") with the results of the run, or can be set up
to raise [`ProcessError`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.ProcessError "asyncssh.ProcessError") if the process exits with a non-zero exit
status. It can also raise [`TimeoutError`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.TimeoutError "asyncssh.TimeoutError") if a specified timeout
expires before the process exits.

The client can also set up TCP port forwarding by calling
[`forward_local_port()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.forward_local_port "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.forward_local_port") or
[`forward_remote_port()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.forward_remote_port "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.forward_remote_port") and
UNIX domain socket forwarding by calling [`forward_local_path()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.forward_local_path "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.forward_local_path") or [`forward_remote_path()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.forward_remote_path "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.forward_remote_path"). Mixed forwarding from a TCP port
to a UNIX domain socket or vice-versa can be set up using the functions
[`forward_local_port_to_path()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.forward_local_port_to_path "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.forward_local_port_to_path"),
[`forward_local_path_to_port()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.forward_local_path_to_port "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.forward_local_path_to_port"),
[`forward_remote_port_to_path()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.forward_remote_port_to_path "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.forward_remote_port_to_path"), and
[`forward_remote_path_to_port()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.forward_remote_path_to_port "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.forward_remote_path_to_port"). In these cases, data
transfer on the channels is managed automatically by AsyncSSH whenever new
connections are opened, so custom session objects are not required.

Dynamic TCP port forwarding can be set up by calling [`forward_socks()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.forward_socks "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.forward_socks"). The SOCKS listener set up by
AsyncSSH on the requested port accepts SOCKS connect requests and is
compatible with SOCKS versions 4, 4a, and 5.

Bidirectional packet forwarding at layer 2 or 3 is also supported using
the functions [`forward_tun()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.forward_tun "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.forward_tun") and
[`forward_tap()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.forward_tap "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.forward_tap") to set up tunnels
between local and remote TUN or TAP interfaces. Once a tunnel is established,
packets arriving on TUN/TAP interfaces on either side are sent over the
tunnel and automatically sent out the TUN/TAP interface on the other side.

When an SSH server receives a new connection and authentication is successful,
handlers such as [`session_requested()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServer.session_requested "asyncssh.SSHServer.session_requested"),
[`connection_requested()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServer.connection_requested "asyncssh.SSHServer.connection_requested"),
[`unix_connection_requested()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServer.unix_connection_requested "asyncssh.SSHServer.unix_connection_requested"),
[`server_requested()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServer.server_requested "asyncssh.SSHServer.server_requested"), and
[`unix_server_requested()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServer.unix_server_requested "asyncssh.SSHServer.unix_server_requested") on the
associated [`SSHServer`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServer "asyncssh.SSHServer") object will be called when clients attempt to
open channels or set up listeners. These methods return coroutines which can
set up the requested sessions or connections, returning
[`SSHServerSession`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerSession "asyncssh.SSHServerSession") or [`SSHTCPSession`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHTCPSession "asyncssh.SSHTCPSession") objects or handler
functions that accept [`SSHReader`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHReader "asyncssh.SSHReader") and [`SSHWriter`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHWriter "asyncssh.SSHWriter") objects
as arguments which manage the channels once they are open.

To better support interactive server applications, AsyncSSH defaults to
providing echoing of input and basic line editing capabilities when an
inbound SSH session requests a pseudo-terminal. This behavior can be
disabled by setting the `line_editor` argument to `False` when
starting up an SSH server. When this feature is enabled, server sessions
can enable or disable line mode using the [`set_line_mode()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHLineEditorChannel.set_line_mode "asyncssh.SSHLineEditorChannel.set_line_mode") method of [`SSHLineEditorChannel`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHLineEditorChannel "asyncssh.SSHLineEditorChannel").
They can also enable or disable input echoing using the [`set_echo()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHLineEditorChannel.set_echo "asyncssh.SSHLineEditorChannel.set_echo") method. Handling of specific keys during
line editing can be customized using the [`register_key()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHLineEditorChannel.register_key "asyncssh.SSHLineEditorChannel.register_key") and [`unregister_key()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHLineEditorChannel.unregister_key "asyncssh.SSHLineEditorChannel.unregister_key") methods.

Each session object also has an associated [`SSHClientChannel`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientChannel "asyncssh.SSHClientChannel"),
[`SSHServerChannel`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerChannel "asyncssh.SSHServerChannel"), or [`SSHTCPChannel`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHTCPChannel "asyncssh.SSHTCPChannel") object passed to it
which can be used to perform actions on the channel. These channel objects
provide a superset of the functionality found in `asyncio` transport
objects.

In addition to the above functions and classes, helper functions for importing
public and private keys can be found below under [Public Key Support](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#publickeysupport),
exceptions can be found under [Exceptions](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#exceptions), supported algorithms can
be found under [Supported Algorithms](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#supportedalgorithms), and some useful constants can be
found under [Constants](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#constants).

## Main Functions [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#main-functions "Link to this heading")

asyncssh.connect( _host=''_, _port=()_, _\*_, _tunnel=()_, _family=()_, _flags=0_, _local_addr=()_, _sock=None_, _config=()_, _options=None_, _\*\*kwargs_) [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/connection.html#connect) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.connect "Link to this definition")

Make an SSH client connection

This function is a coroutine which can be run to create an outbound SSH
client connection to the specified host and port.

When successful, the following steps occur:

> 1. The connection is established and an instance of
>    [`SSHClientConnection`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection") is created to represent it.
>
> 2. The `client_factory` is called without arguments and should
>    return an instance of [`SSHClient`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClient "asyncssh.SSHClient") or a subclass.
>
> 3. The client object is tied to the connection and its
>    [`connection_made()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClient.connection_made "asyncssh.SSHClient.connection_made") method
>    is called.
>
> 4. The SSH handshake and authentication process is initiated,
>    calling methods on the client object if needed.
>
> 5. When authentication completes successfully, the client’s
>    [`auth_completed()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClient.auth_completed "asyncssh.SSHClient.auth_completed") method is
>    called.
>
> 6. The coroutine returns the [`SSHClientConnection`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection"). At
>    this point, the connection is ready for sessions to be opened
>    or port forwarding to be set up.

If an error occurs, it will be raised as an exception and the partially
open connection and client objects will be cleaned up.

Parameters:

- **host** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  The hostname or address to connect to.

- **port** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  The port number to connect to. If not specified, the default
  SSH port is used.

- **tunnel** ( [`SSHClientConnection`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection") or [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) –

(optional)
An existing SSH client connection that this new connection should
be tunneled over. If set, a direct TCP/IP tunnel will be opened
over this connection to the requested host and port rather than
connecting directly via TCP. A string of the form
\[user@\]host\[:port\] may also be specified, in which case a
connection will be made to that host and then used as a tunnel.
A comma-separated list may also be specified to establish a
tunnel through multiple hosts.

> Note
>
> When specifying tunnel as a string, any config
> options in the call will apply only when opening
> a connection to the final destination host and
> port. However, settings to use when opening
> tunnels may be specified via a configuration file.
> To get more control of config options used to
> open the tunnel, [`connect()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.connect "asyncssh.connect") can be called
> explicitly, and the resulting client connection
> can be passed as the tunnel argument.

- **family** ( [`socket.AF_UNSPEC`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/socket.html#socket.AF_UNSPEC "(in Python v3.13)"), [`socket.AF_INET`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/socket.html#socket.AF_INET "(in Python v3.13)"), or [`socket.AF_INET6`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/socket.html#socket.AF_INET6 "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  The address family to use when creating the socket. By default,
  the address family is automatically selected based on the host.

- **flags** (flags to pass to `getaddrinfo()`) – (optional)
  The flags to pass to getaddrinfo() when looking up the host address

- **local_addr** (tuple of [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") and [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  The host and port to bind the socket to before connecting

- **sock** ( [`socket.socket`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/socket.html#socket.socket "(in Python v3.13)") or [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  An existing already-connected socket to run SSH over, instead of
  opening up a new connection. When this is specified, none of
  host, port family, flags, or local_addr should be specified.

- **config** ( [`list`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#list "(in Python v3.13)") of [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  Paths to OpenSSH client configuration files to load. This
  configuration will be used as a fallback to override the
  defaults for settings which are not explicitly specified using
  AsyncSSH’s configuration options. If no paths are specified and
  no config paths were set when constructing the `options`
  argument (if any), an attempt will be made to load the
  configuration from the file `.ssh/config`. If this
  argument is explicitly set to [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)"), no new configuration
  files will be loaded, but any configuration loaded when
  constructing the `options` argument will still apply. See
  [Supported client config options](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#supportedclientconfigoptions) for details on what
  configuration options are currently supported.

- **options** ( [`SSHClientConnectionOptions`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnectionOptions "asyncssh.SSHClientConnectionOptions")) – (optional)
  Options to use when establishing the SSH client connection. These
  options can be specified either through this parameter or as direct
  keyword arguments to this function.

Returns:

[`SSHClientConnection`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection")

asyncssh.connect_reverse( _host=''_, _port=()_, _\*_, _tunnel=()_, _family=()_, _flags=0_, _local_addr=()_, _sock=None_, _config=()_, _options=None_, _\*\*kwargs_) [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/connection.html#connect_reverse) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.connect_reverse "Link to this definition")

Create a reverse direction SSH connection

This function is a coroutine which behaves similar to [`connect()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.connect "asyncssh.connect"),
making an outbound TCP connection to a remote server. However, instead
of starting up an SSH client which runs on that outbound connection,
this function starts up an SSH server, expecting the remote system to
start up a reverse-direction SSH client.

Arguments to this function are the same as [`connect()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.connect "asyncssh.connect"), except
that the `options` are of type [`SSHServerConnectionOptions`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerConnectionOptions "asyncssh.SSHServerConnectionOptions")
instead of [`SSHClientConnectionOptions`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnectionOptions "asyncssh.SSHClientConnectionOptions").

Parameters:

- **host** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  The hostname or address to connect to.

- **port** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  The port number to connect to. If not specified, the default
  SSH port is used.

- **tunnel** ( [`SSHClientConnection`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection") or [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) –

(optional)
An existing SSH client connection that this new connection should
be tunneled over. If set, a direct TCP/IP tunnel will be opened
over this connection to the requested host and port rather than
connecting directly via TCP. A string of the form
\[user@\]host\[:port\] may also be specified, in which case a
connection will be made to that host and then used as a tunnel.
A comma-separated list may also be specified to establish a
tunnel through multiple hosts.

> Note
>
> When specifying tunnel as a string, any config
> options in the call will apply only when opening
> a connection to the final destination host and
> port. However, settings to use when opening
> tunnels may be specified via a configuration file.
> To get more control of config options used to
> open the tunnel, [`connect()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.connect "asyncssh.connect") can be called
> explicitly, and the resulting client connection
> can be passed as the tunnel argument.

- **family** ( [`socket.AF_UNSPEC`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/socket.html#socket.AF_UNSPEC "(in Python v3.13)"), [`socket.AF_INET`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/socket.html#socket.AF_INET "(in Python v3.13)"), or [`socket.AF_INET6`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/socket.html#socket.AF_INET6 "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  The address family to use when creating the socket. By default,
  the address family is automatically selected based on the host.

- **flags** (flags to pass to `getaddrinfo()`) – (optional)
  The flags to pass to getaddrinfo() when looking up the host address

- **local_addr** (tuple of [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") and [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  The host and port to bind the socket to before connecting

- **sock** ( [`socket.socket`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/socket.html#socket.socket "(in Python v3.13)") or [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  An existing already-connected socket to run SSH over, instead of
  opening up a new connection. When this is specified, none of
  host, port family, flags, or local_addr should be specified.

This function is a coroutine which behaves similar to [`listen()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.listen "asyncssh.listen"),
creating a listener which accepts inbound connections on the specified
host and port. However, instead of starting up an SSH server on each
inbound connection, it starts up a reverse-direction SSH client,
expecting the remote system making the connection to start up a
reverse-direction SSH server.

Arguments to this function are the same as [`listen()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.listen "asyncssh.listen"), except
that the `options` are of type [`SSHClientConnectionOptions`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnectionOptions "asyncssh.SSHClientConnectionOptions")
instead of [`SSHServerConnectionOptions`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerConnectionOptions "asyncssh.SSHServerConnectionOptions").

The return value is an [`SSHAcceptor`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHAcceptor "asyncssh.SSHAcceptor") which can be used to
shut down the reverse listener.

Create an SSH client connection

This is a coroutine which wraps around [`connect()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.connect "asyncssh.connect"), providing
backward compatibility with older AsyncSSH releases. The only
differences are that the `client_factory` argument is the first
positional argument in this call rather than being a keyword argument
or specified via an [`SSHClientConnectionOptions`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnectionOptions "asyncssh.SSHClientConnectionOptions") object and
the return value is a tuple of an [`SSHClientConnection`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection") and
[`SSHClient`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClient "asyncssh.SSHClient") rather than just the connection, mirroring
`asyncio.AbstractEventLoop.create_connection()`.

Returns:

An [`SSHClientConnection`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection") and [`SSHClient`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClient "asyncssh.SSHClient")

mirroring `asyncio.AbstractEventLoop.create_server()`.

Retrieve an SSH server’s host key

This is a coroutine which can be run to connect to an SSH server and
return the server host key presented during the SSH handshake.

A list of server host key algorithms can be provided to specify
which host key types the server is allowed to choose from. If the
key exchange is successful, the server host key sent during the
handshake is returned.

> Note
>
> Not all key exchange methods involve the server
> presenting a host key. If something like GSS key
> exchange is used without a server host key, this
> method may return [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)") even when the handshake

_async_ asyncssh.get_server_auth_methods( _host=''_, _port=()_, _username=()_, _\*_, _tunnel=()_, _proxy_command=()_, _family=()_, _flags=0_, _local_addr=()_, _sock=None_, _client_version=()_, _kex_algs=()_, _server_host_key_algs=()_, _config=()_, _options=None_) [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/connection.html#get_server_auth_methods) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.get_server_auth_methods "Link to this definition")

Retrieve an SSH server’s allowed auth methods

This is a coroutine which can be run to connect to an SSH server and
return the auth methods available to authenticate to it.

> Note
>
> The key exchange with the server must complete
> successfully before the list of available auth
> methods can be returned, so be sure to specify any
> arguments needed to complete the key exchange.
> Also, auth methods may vary by user, so you may
> want to specify the specific user you would like
> to get auth methods for.

Parameters:

- **host** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  The hostname or address to connect to

- **port** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  The port number to connect to. If not specified, the default
  SSH port is used.

- **username** – (optional)
  Username to authenticate as on the server. If not specified,
  the currently logged in user on the local machine will be used.

- **tunnel** ( [`SSHClientConnection`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection") or [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) –

(optional)
An existing SSH client connection that this new connection should
be tunneled over. If set, a direct TCP/IP tunnel will be opened
over this connection to the requested host and port rather than
connecting directly via TCP. A string of the form
\[user@\]host\[:port\] may also be specified, in which case a
connection will be made to that host and then used as a tunnel.
A comma-separated list may also be specified to establish a
tunnel through multiple hosts.

> Note

> open the tunnel, [`connect()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.connect "asyncssh.connect") can be called
> explicitly, and the resulting client connection
> can be passed as the tunnel argument.

_async_ asyncssh.scp( _srcpaths_, _dstpath=None_, _\*_, _preserve=False_, _recurse=False_, _block_size=262144_, _progress_handler=None_, _error_handler=None_, _\*\*kwargs_) [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/scp.html#scp) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.scp "Link to this definition")

Copy files using SCP

This function is a coroutine which copies one or more files or
directories using the SCP protocol. Source and destination paths
can be [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") or [`bytes`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#bytes "(in Python v3.13)") values to reference local files or can be
a tuple of the form `(conn, path)` where `conn` is an open
[`SSHClientConnection`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection") to reference files and directories
on a remote system.

For convenience, a host name or tuple of the form `(host, port)`
can be provided in place of the [`SSHClientConnection`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection") to
request that a new SSH connection be opened to a host using
default connect arguments. A [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") or [`bytes`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#bytes "(in Python v3.13)") value of the form
`'host:path'` may also be used in place of the `(conn, path)`
tuple to make a new connection to the requested host on the
default SSH port.

Either a single source path or a sequence of source paths can be
provided, and each path can contain ‘\*’ and ‘?’ wildcard characters
which can be used to match multiple source files or directories.

When copying a single file or directory, the destination path
can be either the full path to copy data into or the path to an
existing directory where the data should be placed. In the latter
case, the base file name from the source path will be used as the
destination name.

When copying multiple files, the destination path must refer to
a directory. If it doesn’t already exist, a directory will be
created with that name.

If the destination path is an [`SSHClientConnection`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection") without
a path or the path provided is empty, files are copied into the
default destination working directory.

If preserve is [`True`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True "(in Python v3.13)"), the access and modification times and
permissions of the original files and directories are set on the
copied files. However, do to the timing of when this information
is sent, the preserved access time will be what was set on the
source file before the copy begins. So, the access time on the
source file will no longer match the destination after the
transfer completes.

If recurse is [`True`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True "(in Python v3.13)") and the source path points at a directory,
the entire subtree under that directory is copied.

Symbolic links found on the source will have the contents of their
target copied rather than creating a destination symbolic link.
When using this option during a recursive copy, one needs to watch
out for links that result in loops. SCP does not provide a
mechanism for preserving links. If you need this, consider using
SFTP instead.

The block_size value controls the size of read and write operations
issued to copy the files. It defaults to 256 KB.

If progress_handler is specified, it will be called after each
block of a file is successfully copied. The arguments passed to
this handler will be the relative path of the file being copied,
bytes copied so far, and total bytes in the file being copied. If
multiple source paths are provided or recurse is set to [`True`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True "(in Python v3.13)"),
the progress_handler will be called consecutively on each file
being copied.

If error_handler is specified and an error occurs during the copy,
this handler will be called with the exception instead of it being
raised. This is intended to primarily be used when multiple source
paths are provided or when recurse is set to [`True`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True "(in Python v3.13)"), to allow
error information to be collected without aborting the copy of the
remaining files. The error handler can raise an exception if it
wants the copy to completely stop. Otherwise, after an error, the
copy will continue starting with the next file.

If any other keyword arguments are specified, they will be passed
to the AsyncSSH connect() call when attempting to open any new SSH
connections needed to perform the file transfer.

Parameters:

- **srcpaths** – The paths of the source files or directories to copy

- **dstpath** – (optional)
  The path of the destination file or directory to copy into

- **preserve** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  Whether or not to preserve the original file attributes

- **recurse** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  Whether or not to recursively copy directories

- **block_size** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  The block size to use for file reads and writes

- **progress_handler** ( [`callable`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#callable "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  The function to call to report copy progress

- **error_handler** ( [`callable`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#callable "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  The function to call when an error occurs

Raises:

[`OSError`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/exceptions.html#OSError "(in Python v3.13)") if a local file I/O error occurs

[`SFTPError`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SFTPError "asyncssh.SFTPError") if the server returns an error

[`ValueError`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/exceptions.html#ValueError "(in Python v3.13)") if both source and destination are local

## Main Classes [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#main-classes "Link to this heading")

_class_ asyncssh.SSHClient [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/client.html#SSHClient) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClient "Link to this definition")

SSH client protocol handler

Applications may subclass this when implementing an SSH client
to receive callbacks when certain events occur on the SSH
connection.

Whenever a new SSH client connection is opened, a corresponding
SSHClient object is created and the method [`connection_made()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClient.connection_made "asyncssh.SSHClient.connection_made")
is called, passing in the [`SSHClientConnection`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection") object.

When the connection is closed, the method [`connection_lost()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClient.connection_lost "asyncssh.SSHClient.connection_lost")
is called with an exception representing the reason for the
disconnect, or [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)") if the connection was closed cleanly.

For simple password or public key based authentication, nothing
needs to be defined here if the password or client keys are passed
in when the connection is created. However, to prompt interactively
or otherwise dynamically select these values, the methods
[`password_auth_requested()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClient.password_auth_requested "asyncssh.SSHClient.password_auth_requested") and/or [`public_key_auth_requested()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClient.public_key_auth_requested "asyncssh.SSHClient.public_key_auth_requested")
can be defined. Keyboard-interactive authentication is also supported
via [`kbdint_auth_requested()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClient.kbdint_auth_requested "asyncssh.SSHClient.kbdint_auth_requested") and [`kbdint_challenge_received()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClient.kbdint_challenge_received "asyncssh.SSHClient.kbdint_challenge_received").

If the server sends an authentication banner, the method
[`auth_banner_received()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClient.auth_banner_received "asyncssh.SSHClient.auth_banner_received") will be called.

If the server requires a password change, the method
[`password_change_requested()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClient.password_change_requested "asyncssh.SSHClient.password_change_requested") will be called, followed by either
[`password_changed()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClient.password_changed "asyncssh.SSHClient.password_changed") or [`password_change_failed()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClient.password_change_failed "asyncssh.SSHClient.password_change_failed") depending
on whether the password change is successful.

Note

The authentication callbacks described here can be
defined as coroutines. However, they may be cancelled if
they are running when the SSH connection is closed by
the server. If they attempt to catch the CancelledError
exception to perform cleanup, they should make sure to
re-raise it to allow AsyncSSH to finish its own cleanup.

However, for more flexibility<br>in matching on the allowed set of keys, this method can be<br>implemented by the application to do the matching itself. It<br>should return [`True`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True "(in Python v3.13)") if the specified key is a valid certificate<br>authority key for the server being connected to.<br>By default, this method returns [`False`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#False "(in Python v3.13)") for all CA keys.<br>> Note<br>> <br>> This function only needs to report whether the<br>> public key provided is a valid CA key for this<br>> host. If it is, AsyncSSH will verify that the<br>> certificate is valid, that the host is one of<br>> the valid principals for the certificate, and<br>> that the server possesses the private key<br>> corresponding to the public key in the certificate<br>> before allowing the validation to succeed.<br>Parameters:<br>- **host** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – The hostname of the target host<br> <br>- **addr** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – The IP address of the target host<br> <br>- **port** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – The port number on the target host<br> <br>- **key** ( [`SSHKey`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHKey "asyncssh.SSHKey") _public key_) – The public key which signed the certificate sent by the server<br> <br>Returns:<br>A [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)") indicating if the specified key is a valid<br>CA key for the target host |     |

_class_ asyncssh.SSHServer [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/server.html#SSHServer) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServer "Link to this definition")

SSH server protocol handler

Applications may subclass this when implementing an SSH server to
provide custom authentication and request handlers.

Whenever a new SSH server connection is accepted, a corresponding
SSHServer object is created and the method [`connection_made()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServer.connection_made "asyncssh.SSHServer.connection_made")
is called, passing in the [`SSHServerConnection`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerConnection "asyncssh.SSHServerConnection") object.

When the connection is closed, the method [`connection_lost()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServer.connection_lost "asyncssh.SSHServer.connection_lost")
is called with an exception representing the reason for the
disconnect, or [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)") if the connection was closed cleanly.

The method [`begin_auth()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServer.begin_auth "asyncssh.SSHServer.begin_auth") can be overridden decide whether
or not authentication is required, and additional callbacks are
provided for each form of authentication in cases where authentication
information is not provided in the call to [`create_server()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.create_server "asyncssh.create_server").

In addition, the methods [`session_requested()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServer.session_requested "asyncssh.SSHServer.session_requested"),
[`connection_requested()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServer.connection_requested "asyncssh.SSHServer.connection_requested"), [`server_requested()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServer.server_requested "asyncssh.SSHServer.server_requested"),
[`unix_connection_requested()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServer.unix_connection_requested "asyncssh.SSHServer.unix_connection_requested"), or [`unix_server_requested()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServer.unix_server_requested "asyncssh.SSHServer.unix_server_requested")
can be overridden to handle requests to open sessions or direct
connections or set up listeners for forwarded connections.

Note

The authentication callbacks described here can be
defined as coroutines. However, they may be cancelled if
they are running when the SSH connection is closed by
the client. If they attempt to catch the CancelledError
exception to perform cleanup, they should make sure to
re-raise it to allow AsyncSSH to finish its own cleanup.

| validate_password( _username_, _password_) [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/server.html#SSHServer.validate_password) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServer.validate_password "Link to this definition")<br>Return whether password is valid for this user<br>This method should return [`True`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True "(in Python v3.13)") if the specified password<br>is a valid password for the user being authenticated. | change_password( _username_, _old_password_, _new_password_) [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/server.html#SSHServer.change_password) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServer.change_password "Link to this definition")<br>Handle a request to change a user’s password<br>This method is called when a user makes a request to<br>change their password. It should first validate that<br>the old password provided is correct and then attempt<br>to change the user’s password to the new value.<br>If the old password provided is valid and the change to<br>the new password is successful, this method should<br>return [`True`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True "(in Python v3.13)"). It may also raise [`PasswordChangeRequired`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.PasswordChangeRequired "asyncssh.PasswordChangeRequired")<br>to request that the client try again if the new password<br>is not acceptable for some reason.<br>If blocking operations need to be performed to determine the<br>validity of the old password or to change to the new password,<br>this method may be defined as a coroutine.<br>By default, this method returns [`False`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#False "(in Python v3.13)"), rejecting all<br>password changes.<br>Parameters:<br>- **username** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – The user whose password should be changed<br> <br>- **old_password** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – The user’s current password<br> <br>- **new_password** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – The new password being requested<br> <br>Returns:<br>A [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)") indicating if the password change<br>is successful or not<br>Raises:<br>[`PasswordChangeRequired`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.PasswordChangeRequired "asyncssh.PasswordChangeRequired") if the new password<br>is not acceptable and the client should be asked<br>to provide another                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             |     |

| session_requested() [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/server.html#SSHServer.session_requested) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServer.session_requested "Link to this definition")<br>Handle an incoming session request<br>This method is called when a session open request is received<br>from the client, indicating it wishes to open a channel to be<br>used for running a shell, executing a command, or connecting<br>to a subsystem. If the application wishes to accept the session,<br>it must override this method to return either an<br>[`SSHServerSession`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerSession "asyncssh.SSHServerSession") object to use to process<br>the data received on the channel or a tuple consisting of an<br>[`SSHServerChannel`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerChannel "asyncssh.SSHServerChannel") object created with<br>[`create_server_channel`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerConnection.create_server_channel "asyncssh.SSHServerConnection.create_server_channel") and an<br>[`SSHServerSession`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerSession "asyncssh.SSHServerSession"), if the application<br>wishes to pass non-default arguments when creating the channel.<br>If blocking operations need to be performed before the session<br>can be created, a coroutine which returns an<br>[`SSHServerSession`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerSession "asyncssh.SSHServerSession") object can be returned instead of<br>the session itself. This can be either returned directly or as<br>a part of a tuple with an [`SSHServerChannel`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerChannel "asyncssh.SSHServerChannel") object.<br>To reject this request, this method should return [`False`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#False "(in Python v3.13)")<br>to send back a “Session refused” response or raise a<br>[`ChannelOpenError`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.ChannelOpenError "asyncssh.ChannelOpenError") exception with the reason for<br>the failure.<br>The details of what type of session the client wants to start<br>will be delivered to methods on the [`SSHServerSession`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerSession "asyncssh.SSHServerSession")<br>object which is returned, along with other information such<br>as environment variables, terminal type, size, and modes.<br>By default, all session requests are rejected.<br>Returns:<br>One of the following:<br>- An [`SSHServerSession`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerSession "asyncssh.SSHServerSession") object or a coroutine<br> which returns an [`SSHServerSession`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerSession "asyncssh.SSHServerSession")<br> <br>- A tuple consisting of an [`SSHServerChannel`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerChannel "asyncssh.SSHServerChannel")<br> and the above<br> <br>- A [`callable`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#callable "(in Python v3.13)") or coroutine handler function which<br> takes AsyncSSH stream objects for stdin, stdout,<br> and stderr as arguments<br> <br>- A tuple consisting of an [`SSHServerChannel`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerChannel "asyncssh.SSHServerChannel")<br> and the above<br> <br>- [`False`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#False "(in Python v3.13)") to refuse the request<br> <br>Raises:<br>[`ChannelOpenError`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.ChannelOpenError "asyncssh.ChannelOpenError") if the session shouldn’t<br>be accepted ## Connection Classes [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#connection-classes "Link to this heading")

_class_ asyncssh.SSHClientConnection [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/connection.html#SSHClientConnection) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection "Link to this definition")

SSH client connection

This class represents an SSH client connection.

Once authentication is successful on a connection, new client
sessions can be opened by calling [`create_session()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.create_session "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.create_session").

Direct TCP connections can be opened by calling
[`create_connection()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.create_connection "asyncssh.create_connection").

Remote listeners for forwarded TCP connections can be opened by
calling [`create_server()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.create_server "asyncssh.create_server").

Direct UNIX domain socket connections can be opened by calling
[`create_unix_connection()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.create_unix_connection "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.create_unix_connection").

Remote listeners for forwarded UNIX domain socket connections
can be opened by calling [`create_unix_server()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.create_unix_server "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.create_unix_server").

TCP port forwarding can be set up by calling [`forward_local_port()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.forward_local_port "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.forward_local_port")
or [`forward_remote_port()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.forward_remote_port "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.forward_remote_port").

UNIX domain socket forwarding can be set up by calling
[`forward_local_path()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.forward_local_path "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.forward_local_path") or [`forward_remote_path()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.forward_remote_path "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.forward_remote_path").

Mixed forwarding from a TCP port to a UNIX domain socket or
vice-versa can be set up by calling [`forward_local_port_to_path()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.forward_local_port_to_path "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.forward_local_port_to_path"),
[`forward_local_path_to_port()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.forward_local_path_to_port "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.forward_local_path_to_port"),
[`forward_remote_port_to_path()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.forward_remote_port_to_path "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.forward_remote_port_to_path"), or
[`forward_remote_path_to_port()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.forward_remote_path_to_port "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.forward_remote_path_to_port").

| _async_ create_session( _session_factory_, _command=()_, _\*_, _subsystem=()_, _env=()_, _send_env=()_, _request_pty=()_, _term_type=()_, _term_size=()_, _term_modes=()_, _x11_forwarding=()_, _x11_display=()_, _x11_auth_path=()_, _x11_single_connection=()_, _encoding=()_, _errors=()_, _window=()_, _max_pktsize=()_) [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/connection.html#SSHClientConnection.create_session) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.create_session "Link to this definition")<br>Create an SSH client session<br>This method is a coroutine which can be called to create an SSH<br>client session used to execute a command, start a subsystem<br>such as sftp, or if no command or subsystem is specified run an<br>interactive shell. Optional arguments allow terminal and<br>environment information to be provided.<br>By default, this class expects string data in its send and<br>receive functions, which it encodes on the SSH connection in<br>UTF-8 (ISO 10646) format. An optional encoding argument can<br>be passed in to select a different encoding, or [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)") can<br>be passed in if the application wishes to send and receive<br>raw bytes. When an encoding is set, an optional errors<br>argument can be passed in to select what Unicode error<br>handling strategy to use.<br>Other optional arguments include the SSH receive window size and<br>max packet size which default to 2 MB and 32 KB, respectively.<br>Parameters:<br>- **session_factory** ( [`callable`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#callable "(in Python v3.13)")) – A [`callable`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#callable "(in Python v3.13)") which returns an [`SSHClientSession`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientSession "asyncssh.SSHClientSession") object<br> that will be created to handle activity on this session<br> <br>- **command** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> The remote command to execute. By default, an interactive<br> shell is started if no command or subsystem is provided.<br> <br>- **subsystem** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> The name of a remote subsystem to start up.<br> <br>- **env** ( [`dict`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#dict "(in Python v3.13)") with [`bytes`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#bytes "(in Python v3.13)") or [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") keys and values) – <br> <br> (optional)<br> The environment variables to set for this session. Keys and<br> values passed in here will be converted to Unicode strings<br> encoded as UTF-8 (ISO 10646) for transmission.<br> <br> <br> > Note<br> > <br> > Many SSH servers restrict which environment<br> > variables a client is allowed to set. The<br> > server’s configuration may need to be edited<br> > before environment variables can be<br> > successfully set in the remote environment.<br> <br>- **send_env** ( [`list`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#list "(in Python v3.13)") of [`bytes`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#bytes "(in Python v3.13)") or [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> A list of environment variable names to pull from<br> [`os.environ`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/os.html#os.environ "(in Python v3.13)") and set for this session. Wildcards patterns<br> using `'*'` and `'?'` are allowed, and all variables with<br> matching names will be sent with whatever value is set<br> in the local environment. If a variable is present in both<br> env and send_env, the value from env will be used.<br> <br>- **request_pty** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)"), `'force'`, or `'auto'`) – (optional)<br> Whether or not to request a pseudo-terminal (PTY) for this<br> session. This defaults to [`True`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True "(in Python v3.13)"), which means to request a<br> PTY whenever the `term_type` is set. Other possible values<br> include [`False`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#False "(in Python v3.13)") to never request a PTY, `'force'` to always<br> request a PTY even without `term_type` being set, or `'auto'`<br> to request a TTY when `term_type` is set but only when<br> starting an interactive shell.<br> <br>- **term_type** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> The terminal type to set for this session.<br> <br>- **term_size** ( [`tuple`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#tuple "(in Python v3.13)") of 2 or 4 [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)") values) – (optional)<br> The terminal width and height in characters and optionally<br> the width and height in pixels.<br> <br>- **term_modes** ( [`dict`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#dict "(in Python v3.13)") with [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)") keys and values) – (optional)<br> POSIX terminal modes to set for this session, where keys are<br> taken from [POSIX terminal modes](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#ptymodes) with values<br> defined in section 8 of [**RFC 4254**](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc4254.html#section-8).<br> <br>- **x11_forwarding** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)") or `'ignore_failure'`) – (optional)<br> Whether or not to request X11 forwarding for this session,<br> defaulting to [`False`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#False "(in Python v3.13)"). If set to [`True`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True "(in Python v3.13)"), X11 forwarding will<br> be requested and a failure will raise [`ChannelOpenError`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.ChannelOpenError "asyncssh.ChannelOpenError").<br> It can also be set to `'ignore_failure'` to attempt X11<br> forwarding but ignore failures.<br> <br>- **x11_display** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> The display that X11 connections should be forwarded to,<br> defaulting to the value in the environment variable `DISPLAY`.<br> <br>- **x11_auth_path** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> The path to the Xauthority file to read X11 authentication<br> data from, defaulting to the value in the environment variable<br> `XAUTHORITY` or the file `.Xauthority` in the "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.create_session") are supported and have the same meaning. | create_process( _\*args_, _bufsize=io.DEFAULT_BUFFER_SIZE_, _input=None_, _stdin=PIPE_, _stdout=PIPE_, _stderr=PIPE_, _\*\*kwargs_) [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/connection.html#SSHClientConnection.create_process) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.create_process "Link to this definition")<br>Create a process on the remote system<br>This method is a coroutine wrapper around [`create_session()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.create_session "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.create_session")<br>which can be used to execute a command, start a subsystem,<br>or start an interactive shell, optionally redirecting stdin,<br>stdout, and stderr to and from files or pipes attached to<br>other local and remote processes.<br>By default, the stdin, stdout, and stderr arguments default<br>to the special value `PIPE` which means that they can be<br>read and written interactively via stream objects which are<br>members of the [`SSHClientProcess`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientProcess "asyncssh.SSHClientProcess") object this method<br>returns. If other file-like objects are provided as arguments,<br>input or output will automatically be redirected to them. The<br>special value `DEVNULL` can be used to provide no input or<br>discard all output, and the special value `STDOUT` can be<br>provided as `stderr` to send its output to the same stream<br>as `stdout`.<br>In addition to the arguments below, all arguments to<br>[`create_session()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.create_session "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.create_session") except for `session_factory` are<br>supported and have the same meaning.<br>Parameters:<br>- **input** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") or [`bytes`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#bytes "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> Input data to feed to standard input of the remote process.<br> If specified, this argument takes precedence over stdin.<br> Data should be a [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") if encoding is set, or [`bytes`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#bytes "(in Python v3.13)") if not.<br> <br>- **stdin** – (optional)<br> A filename, file-like object, file descriptor, socket, or<br> [`SSHReader`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHReader "asyncssh.SSHReader") to feed to standard input of the remote<br> process, or `DEVNULL` to provide no input.<br> <br>- **stdout** – (optional)<br> A filename, file-like object, file descriptor, socket, or<br> [`SSHWriter`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHWriter "asyncssh.SSHWriter") to feed standard output of the remote<br> process to, or `DEVNULL` to discard this output.<br> <br>- **stderr** – (optional)<br> A filename, file-like object, file descriptor, socket, or<br> [`SSHWriter`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHWriter "asyncssh.SSHWriter") to feed standard error of the remote<br> process to, `DEVNULL` to discard this output, or `STDOUT`<br> to feed standard error to the same place as stdout.<br> <br>- **bufsize** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> Buffer size to use when feeding data from a file to stdin<br> <br>- **send_eof** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)")) – Whether or not to send EOF to the channel when EOF is<br> received from stdin, defaulting to [`True`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True "(in Python v3.13)"). If set to [`False`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#False "(in Python v3.13)"),<br> the channel will remain open after EOF is received on stdin,<br> and multiple sources can be redirected to the channel.<br> <br>- **recv_eof** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)")) – Whether or not to send EOF to stdout and stderr when EOF is<br> received from the channel, defaulting to [`True`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True "(in Python v3.13)"). If set to<br> [`False`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#False "(in Python v3.13)"), the redirect targets of stdout and stderr will remain<br> open after EOF is received on the channel and can be used for<br> multiple redirects.<br> <br>Returns:<br>[`SSHClientProcess`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientProcess "asyncssh.SSHClientProcess")<br>Raises:<br>[`ChannelOpenError`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.ChannelOpenError "asyncssh.ChannelOpenError") if the channel can’t be opened this<br>session.<br>Returns:<br>an [`SSHSubprocessTransport`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHSubprocessTransport "asyncssh.SSHSubprocessTransport") | _async_ run( _\*args_, _check=False_, _timeout=None_, _\*\*kwargs_) [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/connection.html#SSHClientConnection.run) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.run "Link to this definition")<br>Run a command on the remote system and collect its output<br>This method is a coroutine wrapper around [`create_process()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.create_process "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.create_process")<br>which can be used to run a process to completion when no<br>interactivity is needed. All of the arguments to<br>[`create_process()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.create_process "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.create_process") can be passed in to provide input or<br>redirect stdin, stdout, and stderr, but this method waits until<br>the process exits and returns an [`SSHCompletedProcess`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHCompletedProcess "asyncssh.SSHCompletedProcess")<br>object with the exit status or signal information and the<br>output to stdout and stderr (if not redirected).<br>If the check argument is set to [`True`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True "(in Python v3.13)"), a non-zero exit status<br>from the remote process will trigger the [`ProcessError`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.ProcessError "asyncssh.ProcessError")<br>exception to be raised.<br>In addition to the argument below, all arguments to<br>[`create_process()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.create_process "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.create_process") are supported and have the same meaning.<br>If a timeout is specified and it expires before the process<br>exits, the [`TimeoutError`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.TimeoutError "asyncssh.TimeoutError") exception will be raised. By<br>default, no timeout is set and this call will wait indefinitely.<br>Parameters:<br>- **check** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> Whether or not to raise [`ProcessError`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.ProcessError "asyncssh.ProcessError") when a non-zero<br> exit status is returned<br> <br>- **timeout** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)"), [`float`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#float "(in Python v3.13)"), or [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)")) – Amount of time in seconds to wait for process to exit or<br> [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)") to wait indefinitely<br> <br>Returns:<br>[`SSHCompletedProcess`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHCompletedProcess "asyncssh.SSHCompletedProcess")<br>Raises:<br>[`ChannelOpenError`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.ChannelOpenError "asyncssh.ChannelOpenError") if the session can’t be opened<br>[`ProcessError`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.ProcessError "asyncssh.ProcessError") if checking non-zero exit status<br>[`TimeoutError`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.TimeoutError "asyncssh.TimeoutError") if the timeout expires before exit | start_sftp_client( _env=()_, _send_env=()_, _path_encoding='utf-8'_, _path_errors='strict'_, _sftp_version=3_) [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/connection.html#SSHClientConnection.start_sftp_client) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.start_sftp_client "Link to this definition")<br>Start an SFTP client<br>This method is a coroutine which attempts to start a secure<br>file transfer session. If it succeeds, it returns an<br>[`SFTPClient`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SFTPClient "asyncssh.SFTPClient") object which can be used to copy and<br>access files on the remote host.<br>An optional Unicode encoding can be specified for sending and<br>receiving pathnames, defaulting to UTF-8 with strict error<br>checking. If an encoding of [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)") is specified, pathnames<br>will be left as bytes rather than being converted to & from<br>strings.<br>Parameters:<br>- **env** ( [`dict`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#dict "(in Python v3.13)") with [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") keys and values) – <br> <br> (optional)<br> The environment variables to set for this SFTP session. Keys<br> and values passed in here will be converted to Unicode<br> strings encoded as UTF-8 (ISO 10646) for transmission.<br> <br> <br> > Note<br> > <br> > Many SSH servers restrict which environment<br> > variables a client is allowed to set. The<br> > server’s configuration may need to be edited<br> > before environment variables can be<br> > successfully set in the remote environment.<br> <br>- **send_env** ( [`list`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#list "(in Python v3.13)") of [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> A list of environment variable names to pull from<br> [`os.environ`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/os.html#os.environ "(in Python v3.13)") and set for this SFTP session. Wildcards<br> patterns using `'*'` and `'?'` are allowed, and all variables<br> with matching names will be sent with whatever value is set<br> in the local environment. If a variable is present in both<br> env and send_env, the value from env will be used.<br> <br>- **path_encoding** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") or [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)")) – The Unicode encoding to apply when sending and receiving<br> remote pathnames<br> <br>- **path_errors** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – The error handling strategy to apply on encode/decode errors<br> <br>- **sftp_version** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> The maximum version of the SFTP protocol to support, currently<br> either 3 or 4, defaulting to 3.<br> <br>Returns:<br>[`SFTPClient`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SFTPClient "asyncssh.SFTPClient")<br>Raises:<br>[`SFTPError`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SFTPError "asyncssh.SFTPError") if the session can’t be opened
