| _async_ create_connection( _session_factory_, _remote_host_, _remote_port_, _orig_host=''_, _orig_port=0_, _\*_, _encoding=None_, _errors='strict'_, _window=2097152_, _max_pktsize=32768_) [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/connection.html#SSHClientConnection.create_connection) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.create_connection "Link to this definition")<br>Create an SSH TCP direct connection<br>This method is a coroutine which can be called to request that<br>the server open a new outbound TCP connection to the specified<br>destination host and port. If the connection is successfully<br>opened, a new SSH channel will be opened with data being handled<br>by a [`SSHTCPSession`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHTCPSession "asyncssh.SSHTCPSession") object created by `session_factory`.<br>Optional arguments include the host and port of the original<br>client opening the connection when performing TCP port forwarding.<br>By default, this class expects data to be sent and received as<br>raw bytes. However, an optional encoding argument can be passed<br>in to select the encoding to use, allowing the application send<br>and receive string data. When encoding is set, an optional errors<br>argument can be passed in to select what Unicode error handling<br>strategy to use.<br>Other optional arguments include the SSH receive window size and<br>max packet size which default to 2 MB and 32 KB, respectively.<br>Parameters:<br>- **session_factory** ( [`callable`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#callable "(in Python v3.13)")) – A [`callable`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#callable "(in Python v3.13)") which returns an [`SSHTCPSession`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHTCPSession "asyncssh.SSHTCPSession") object<br> that will be created to handle activity on this session<br> <br>- **remote_host** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – The remote hostname or address to connect to<br> <br>- **remote_port** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – The remote port number to connect to<br> <br>- **orig_host** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> The hostname or address of the client requesting the connection<br> <br>- **orig_port** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> The port number of the client requesting the connection<br> <br>- **encoding** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") or [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> The Unicode encoding to use for data exchanged on the connection<br> <br>- **errors** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> The error handling strategy to apply on encode/decode errors<br> <br>- **window** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> The receive window size for this session<br> <br>- **max_pktsize** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> The maximum packet size for this session<br> <br>Returns:<br>an [`SSHTCPChannel`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHTCPChannel "asyncssh.SSHTCPChannel") and [`SSHTCPSession`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHTCPSession "asyncssh.SSHTCPSession")<br>Raises:<br>[`ChannelOpenError`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.ChannelOpenError "asyncssh.ChannelOpenError") if the connection can’t be opened If the request fails,<br>[`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)") is returned.<br>Parameters:<br>- **session_factory** ( [`callable`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#callable "(in Python v3.13)")) – A [`callable`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#callable "(in Python v3.13)") or coroutine which decides whether to accept<br> the connection or not, either returning an<br> [`SSHUNIXSession`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHUNIXSession "asyncssh.SSHUNIXSession") object used to handle activity<br> on that connection or raising [`ChannelOpenError`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.ChannelOpenError "asyncssh.ChannelOpenError")<br> to indicate that the connection should not be accepted<br> <br>- **listen_path** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – The path on the remote host to listen on<br> <br>- **encoding** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") or [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> The Unicode encoding to use for data exchanged on the connection<br> <br>- **errors** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> The error handling strategy to apply on encode/decode errors<br> <br>- **window** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> The receive window size for this session<br> <br>- **max_pktsize** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> The maximum packet size for this session<br> <br>Returns:<br>[`SSHListener`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHListener "asyncssh.SSHListener")<br>Raises:<br>[`ChannelListenError`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.ChannelListenError "asyncssh.ChannelListenError") if the listener can’t be opened | start_unix_server( _handler_factory_, _\*args_, _\*\*kwargs_) [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/connection.html#SSHClientConnection.start_unix_server) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.start_unix_server "Link to this definition")<br>Start a remote SSH UNIX domain socket listener<br>This method is a coroutine wrapper around [`create_unix_server()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.create_unix_server "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.create_unix_server")<br>designed to provide a “high-level” stream interface for creating<br>remote SSH UNIX domain socket listeners. Instead of taking a<br>`session_factory` argument for constructing an object which<br>will handle activity on the session via callbacks, it takes a<br>`handler_factory` which returns a [`callable`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#callable "(in Python v3.13)") or coroutine that<br>will be passed [`SSHReader`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHReader "asyncssh.SSHReader") and [`SSHWriter`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHWriter "asyncssh.SSHWriter") objects<br>which can be used to perform I/O on each new connection which<br>arrives. Like [`create_unix_server()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.create_unix_server "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.create_unix_server"), `handler_factory`<br>can also raise [`ChannelOpenError`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.ChannelOpenError "asyncssh.ChannelOpenError") if the connection should<br>not be accepted.<br>With the exception of `handler_factory` replacing<br>`session_factory`, all of the arguments to<br>[`create_unix_server()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.create_unix_server "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.create_unix_server") are supported and have the same<br>meaning here.<br>Parameters:<br>**handler_factory** ( [`callable`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#callable "(in Python v3.13)") or coroutine) – A [`callable`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#callable "(in Python v3.13)") or coroutine which decides whether to accept<br>the UNIX domain socket connection or not, either returning<br>a callback or coroutine used to handle activity on that<br>connection or raising [`ChannelOpenError`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.ChannelOpenError "asyncssh.ChannelOpenError") to indicate<br>that the connection should not be accepted<br>Returns:<br>[`SSHListener`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHListener "asyncssh.SSHListener")<br>Raises:<br>[`ChannelListenError`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.ChannelListenError "asyncssh.ChannelListenError") if the listener can’t be opened                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           |     |

| abort() [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.abort "Link to this definition")<br>Forcibly close the SSH connection<br>This method closes the SSH connection immediately, without<br>waiting for pending operations to complete and without sending<br>an explicit SSH disconnect message. Buffered data waiting to be<br>sent will be lost and no more data will be received. When the<br>the connection is closed, [`connection_lost()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClient.connection_lost "asyncssh.SSHClient.connection_lost") on the associated [`SSHClient`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClient "asyncssh.SSHClient")<br>object will be called with the value [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)").                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              |     |
| close() [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.close "Link to this definition")<br>Cleanly close the SSH connection<br>This method calls [`disconnect()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.disconnect "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.disconnect") with the reason set to<br>indicate that the connection was closed explicitly by the<br>application.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           |     |
| disconnect( _code_, _reason_, _lang='en-US'_) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.disconnect "Link to this definition")<br>Disconnect the SSH connection<br>This method sends a disconnect message and closes the SSH<br>connection after buffered data waiting to be written has been<br>sent. No more data will be received. When the connection is<br>fully closed, [`connection_lost()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClient.connection_lost "asyncssh.SSHClient.connection_lost")<br>on the associated [`SSHClient`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClient "asyncssh.SSHClient") or [`SSHServer`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServer "asyncssh.SSHServer") object<br>will be called with the value [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)").<br>Parameters:<br>- **code** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – The reason for the disconnect, from<br> [disconnect reason codes](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#disconnectreasons)<br> <br>- **reason** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – A human readable reason for the disconnect<br> <br>- **lang** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – The language the reason is in |     |

_class_ asyncssh.SSHServerConnection [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/connection.html#SSHServerConnection) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerConnection "Link to this definition")

SSH server connection

This class represents an SSH server connection.

During authentication, [`send_auth_banner()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerConnection.send_auth_banner "asyncssh.SSHServerConnection.send_auth_banner") can be called to
send an authentication banner to the client.

Once authenticated, [`SSHServer`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServer "asyncssh.SSHServer") objects wishing to create
session objects with non-default channel properties can call
[`create_server_channel()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerConnection.create_server_channel "asyncssh.SSHServerConnection.create_server_channel") from their [`session_requested()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServer.session_requested "asyncssh.SSHServer.session_requested") method and return a tuple of
the [`SSHServerChannel`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerChannel "asyncssh.SSHServerChannel") object returned from that and either
an [`SSHServerSession`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerSession "asyncssh.SSHServerSession") object or a coroutine which returns
an [`SSHServerSession`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerSession "asyncssh.SSHServerSession").

Similarly, [`SSHServer`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServer "asyncssh.SSHServer") objects wishing to create TCP
connection objects with non-default channel properties can call
[`create_tcp_channel()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerConnection.create_tcp_channel "asyncssh.SSHServerConnection.create_tcp_channel") from their [`connection_requested()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServer.connection_requested "asyncssh.SSHServer.connection_requested") method and return a tuple of
the [`SSHTCPChannel`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHTCPChannel "asyncssh.SSHTCPChannel") object returned from that and either
an [`SSHTCPSession`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHTCPSession "asyncssh.SSHTCPSession") object or a coroutine which returns an
[`SSHTCPSession`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHTCPSession "asyncssh.SSHTCPSession").

[`SSHServer`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServer "asyncssh.SSHServer") objects wishing to create UNIX domain socket
connection objects with non-default channel properties can call
[`create_unix_channel()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerConnection.create_unix_channel "asyncssh.SSHServerConnection.create_unix_channel") from the [`unix_connection_requested()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServer.unix_connection_requested "asyncssh.SSHServer.unix_connection_requested") method and return a tuple of
the [`SSHUNIXChannel`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHUNIXChannel "asyncssh.SSHUNIXChannel") object returned from that and either
an [`SSHUNIXSession`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHUNIXSession "asyncssh.SSHUNIXSession") object or a coroutine which returns an
[`SSHUNIXSession`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHUNIXSession "asyncssh.SSHUNIXSession").

| get_key_option( _option_, _default=None_) [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/connection.html#SSHServerConnection.get_key_option) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerConnection.get_key_option "Link to this definition")<br>Return option from authorized_keys<br>If a client key or certificate was presented during authentication,<br>this method returns the value of the requested option in the<br>corresponding authorized_keys entry if it was set. Otherwise, it<br>returns the default value provided.<br>The following standard options are supported:<br>> command (string)<br>> <br>> environment (dictionary of name/value pairs)<br>> <br>> from (list of host patterns)<br>> <br>> no-touch-required (boolean)<br>> <br>> permitopen (list of host/port tuples)<br>> <br>> principals (list of usernames)<br>Non-standard options are also supported and will return the<br>value [`True`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True "(in Python v3.13)") if the option is present without a value or<br>return a list of strings containing the values associated<br>with each occurrence of that option name. If the option is<br>not present, the specified default value is returned.<br>Parameters:<br>- **option** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – The name of the option to look up.<br> <br>- **default** – The default value to return if the option is not present.<br> <br>Returns:<br>The value of the option in authorized_keys, if set |     |
| check_key_permission( _permission_) [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/connection.html#SSHServerConnection.check_key_permission) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerConnection.check_key_permission "Link to this definition")<br>Check permissions in authorized_keys<br>If a client key or certificate was presented during<br>authentication, this method returns whether the specified<br>permission is allowed by the corresponding authorized_keys<br>entry. By default, all permissions are granted, but they<br>can be revoked by specifying an option starting with<br>‘no-’ without a value.<br>The following standard options are supported:<br>> X11-forwarding<br>> <br>> agent-forwarding<br>> <br>> port-forwarding<br>> <br>> pty<br>> <br>> user-rc<br>AsyncSSH internally enforces X11-forwarding, agent-forwarding,<br>port-forwarding and pty permissions but ignores user-rc since<br>it does not implement that feature.<br>Non-standard permissions can also be checked, as long as the<br>option follows the convention of starting with ‘no-‘.<br>Parameters:<br>**permission** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – The name of the permission to check (without the ‘no-‘).<br>Returns:<br>A [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)") indicating if the permission is granted.                                                                                                                                  |     |
| get_certificate_option( _option_, _default=None_) [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/connection.html#SSHServerConnection.get_certificate_option) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerConnection.get_certificate_option "Link to this definition")<br>Return option from user certificate<br>If a user certificate was presented during authentication,<br>this method returns the value of the requested option in<br>the certificate if it was set. Otherwise, it returns the<br>default value provided.<br>The following options are supported:<br>> force-command (string)<br>> <br>> no-touch-required (boolean)<br>> <br>> source-address (list of CIDR-style IP network addresses)<br>Parameters:<br>- **option** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – The name of the option to look up.<br> <br>- **default** – The default value to return if the option is not present.<br> <br>Returns:<br>The value of the option in the user certificate, if set                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          |     |
| check_certificate_permission( _permission_) [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/connection.html#SSHServerConnection.check_certificate_permission) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerConnection.check_certificate_permission "Link to this definition")<br>Check permissions in user certificate<br>If a user certificate was presented during authentication,<br>this method returns whether the specified permission was<br>granted in the certificate. Otherwise, it acts as if all<br>permissions are granted and returns [`True`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True "(in Python v3.13)").<br>The following permissions are supported:<br>> X11-forwarding<br>> <br>> agent-forwarding<br>> <br>> port-forwarding<br>> <br>> pty<br>> <br>> user-rc<br>AsyncSSH internally enforces agent-forwarding, port-forwarding<br>and pty permissions but ignores the other values since it does<br>not implement those features.<br>Parameters:<br>**permission** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – The name of the permission to check (without the ‘permit-‘).<br>Returns:<br>A [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)") indicating if the permission is granted.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      |     |

| _async_ create_connection( _session_factory_, _remote_host_, _remote_port_, _orig_host=''_, _orig_port=0_, _\*_, _encoding=None_, _errors='strict'_, _window=2097152_, _max_pktsize=32768_) [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/connection.html#SSHServerConnection.create_connection) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerConnection.create_connection "Link to this definition")<br>Create an SSH TCP forwarded connection<br>This method is a coroutine which can be called to notify the<br>client about a new inbound TCP connection arriving on the<br>specified remote host and port. If the connection is successfully<br>opened, a new SSH channel will be opened with data being handled<br>by a [`SSHTCPSession`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHTCPSession "asyncssh.SSHTCPSession") object created by `session_factory`.<br>Optional arguments include the host and port of the original<br>client opening the connection when performing TCP port forwarding.<br>By default, this class expects data to be sent and received as<br>raw bytes. However, an optional encoding argument can be<br>passed in to select the encoding to use, allowing the<br>application to send and receive string data. When encoding is<br>set, an optional errors argument can be passed in to select<br>what Unicode error handling strategy to use.<br>Other optional arguments include the SSH receive window size and<br>max packet size which default to 2 MB and 32 KB, respectively.<br>Parameters:<br>- **session_factory** ( [`callable`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#callable "(in Python v3.13)")) – A [`callable`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#callable "(in Python v3.13)") which returns an [`SSHTCPSession`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHTCPSession "asyncssh.SSHTCPSession") object<br> that will be created to handle activity on this session<br> <br>- **remote_host** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – The hostname or address the connection was received on<br> <br>- **remote_port** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – The port number the connection was received on<br> <br>- **orig_host** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> The hostname or address of the client requesting the connection<br> <br>- **orig_port** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> The port number of the client requesting the connection<br> <br>- **encoding** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") or [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> The Unicode encoding to use for data exchanged on the connection<br> <br>- **errors** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> The error handling strategy to apply on encode/decode errors<br> <br>- **window** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> The receive window size for this session<br> <br>- **max_pktsize** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> The maximum packet size for this session<br> <br>Returns:<br>an [`SSHTCPChannel`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHTCPChannel "asyncssh.SSHTCPChannel") and [`SSHTCPSession`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHTCPSession "asyncssh.SSHTCPSession") |     |
| _async_ open_connection( _\*args_, _\*\*kwargs_) [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/connection.html#SSHServerConnection.open_connection) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerConnection.open_connection "Link to this definition")<br>Open an SSH TCP forwarded connection<br>This method is a coroutine wrapper around [`create_connection()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.create_connection "asyncssh.create_connection")<br>designed to provide a “high-level” stream interface for creating<br>an SSH TCP forwarded connection. the same<br>meaning here.<br>Returns:<br>an [`SSHReader`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHReader "asyncssh.SSHReader") and [`SSHTunTapChannel`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHTunTapChannel "asyncssh.SSHTunTapChannel")<br>with the desired window and max packet size for a newly created<br>TUN/TAP tunnel.<br>Parameters:<br>- **window** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> The receive window size for this session<br> <br>- **max_pktsize** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> The maximum packet size for this session<br> | Connection close methods                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   |     |
| ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | --- |
| abort() [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerConnection.abort "Link to this definition")<br>Forcibly close the SSH connection<br>This method closes the SSH connection immediately, without<br>waiting for pending operations to complete and without sending<br>an explicit SSH disconnect message. Buffered data waiting to be<br>sent will be lost and no more data will be received. When the<br>the connection is closed, [`connection_lost()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClient.connection_lost "asyncssh.SSHClient.connection_lost") on the associated [`SSHClient`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClient "asyncssh.SSHClient")<br>object will be called with the value [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)").                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              |     |
| close() [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerConnection.close "Link to this definition")<br>Cleanly close the SSH connection<br>This method calls [`disconnect()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerConnection.disconnect "asyncssh.SSHServerConnection.disconnect") with the reason set to<br>indicate that the connection was closed explicitly by the<br>application.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           |     |
| disconnect( _code_, _reason_, _lang='en-US'_) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerConnection.disconnect "Link to this definition")<br>Disconnect the SSH connection<br>This method sends a disconnect message and closes the SSH<br>connection after buffered data waiting to be written has been<br>sent. No more data will be received. When the connection is<br>fully closed, [`connection_lost()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClient.connection_lost "asyncssh.SSHClient.connection_lost")<br>on the associated [`SSHClient`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClient "asyncssh.SSHClient") or [`SSHServer`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServer "asyncssh.SSHServer") object<br>will be called with the value [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)").<br>Parameters:<br>- **code** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – The reason for the disconnect, from<br> [disconnect reason codes](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#disconnectreasons)<br> <br>- **reason** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – A human readable reason for the disconnect<br> <br>- **lang** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – The language the reason is in |     |

_class_ asyncssh.SSHClientConnectionOptions [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/connection.html#SSHClientConnectionOptions) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnectionOptions "Link to this definition")

SSH client connection options

The following options are available to control the establishment
of SSH client connections:

Parameters:

- **client_factory** ( [`callable`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#callable "(in Python v3.13)") returning [`SSHClient`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClient "asyncssh.SSHClient")) – (optional)
  A [`callable`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#callable "(in Python v3.13)") which returns an [`SSHClient`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClient "asyncssh.SSHClient") object that will
  be created for each new connection.

- **proxy_command** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") or [`list`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#list "(in Python v3.13)") of [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  A string or list of strings specifying a command and arguments
  to run to make a connection to the SSH server. Data will be
  forwarded to this process over stdin/stdout instead of opening a
  TCP connection. If specified as a string, standard shell quoting
  will be applied when splitting the command and its arguments.

- **known_hosts** ( _see_ [Specifying known hosts](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#specifyingknownhosts)) – (optional)
  The list of keys which will be used to validate the server host
  key presented during the SSH handshake. If this is not specified,
  the keys will be looked up in the file `.ssh/known_hosts`.
  If this is explicitly set to [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)"), server host key validation
  will be disabled.

- **host_key_alias** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  An alias to use instead of the real host name when looking up a host
  key in known_hosts and when validating host certificates.

- **server_host_key_algs** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") or [`list`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#list "(in Python v3.13)") of [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) –

(optional)
A list of server host key algorithms to use instead of the
default of those present in known_hosts when performing the SSH
handshake, taken from [server host key algorithms](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#publickeyalgs). This is useful when using the
validate_host_public_key callback to validate server host keys,
since AsyncSSH can not determine which server host key algorithms
are preferred. This argument can also be set to ‘default’ to
specify that the client should always send its default list of
supported algorithms to avoid leaking information about what
algorithms are present for the server in known_hosts.

> Note
>
> The ‘default’ keyword should be used with
> caution, as it can result in a host key mismatch
> if the client trusts only a subset of the host
> keys the server might return.

- **server_host_keys_handler** ( [`callable`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#callable "(in Python v3.13)") or coroutine) –

(optional)
A [`callable`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#callable "(in Python v3.13)") or coroutine handler function which if set will be
called when a global request from the server is received which
provides an updated list of server host keys. The handler takes
four arguments (added, removed, retained, and revoked), each of
which is a list of SSHKey public keys, reflecting differences
between what the server reported and what is currently matching
in known_hosts.

> Note
>
> This handler will only be called when known
> host checking is enabled and the check succeeded.

- **x509_trusted_certs** ( _see_ [Specifying certificates](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#specifyingcertificates)) –

(optional)
A list of certificates which should be trusted for X.509 server
certificate authentication. If no trusted certificates are
specified, an attempt will be made to load them from the file
`.ssh/ca-bundle.crt`. If this argument is explicitly set
to [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)"), X.509 server certificate authentication will not
be performed.

> Note
>
> X.509 certificates to trust can also be provided
> through a [known_hosts](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#knownhosts) file
> if they are converted into OpenSSH format.
> This allows their trust to be limited to only
> specific host names.

- **x509_trusted_cert_paths** ( [`list`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#list "(in Python v3.13)") of [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  A list of path names to “hash directories” containing certificates
  which should be trusted for X.509 server certificate authentication.
  Each certificate should be in a separate file with a name of the
  form _hash.number_, where _hash_ is the OpenSSL hash value of the
  certificate subject name and _number_ is an integer counting up
  from zero if multiple certificates have the same hash. If no
  paths are specified, an attempt with be made to use the directory
  `.ssh/crt` as a certificate hash directory.

- **x509_purposes** ( _see_ [Specifying X.509 purposes](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#specifyingx509purposes)) – (optional)
  A list of purposes allowed in the ExtendedKeyUsage of a
  certificate used for X.509 server certificate authentication,
  defulting to ‘secureShellServer’. If this argument is explicitly
  set to [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)"), the server certificate’s ExtendedKeyUsage will
  not be checked.

- **username** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  Username to authenticate as on the server. If not specified,
  the currently logged in user on the local machine will be used.

- **password** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  The password to use for client password authentication or
  keyboard-interactive authentication which prompts for a password,
  or a [`callable`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#callable "(in Python v3.13)") or coroutine which returns the password to use.
  If this is not specified or set to [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)"), client password
  authentication will not be performed.

- **client_host_keysign** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)") or [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  Whether or not to use `ssh-keysign` to sign host-based
  authentication requests. If set to [`True`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True "(in Python v3.13)"), an attempt will be
  made to find `ssh-keysign` in its typical locations. If set to
  a string, that will be used as the `ssh-keysign` path. When set,
  client_host_keys should be a list of public keys. Otherwise,
  client_host_keys should be a list of private keys with optional
  paired certificates.

- **client_host_keys** ( _see_ [Specifying private keys](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#specifyingprivatekeys) or [Specifying public keys](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#specifyingpublickeys)) – (optional)
  A list of keys to use to authenticate this client via host-based
  authentication. If `client_host_keysign` is set and no host keys
  or certificates are specified, an attempt will be made to find
  them in their typical locations. If `client_host_keysign` is
  not set, host private keys must be specified explicitly or
  host-based authentication will not be performed.

- **client_host_certs** ( _see_ [Specifying certificates](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#specifyingcertificates)) – (optional)
  A list of optional certificates which can be paired with the
  provided client host keys.

- **client_host** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  The local hostname to use when performing host-based
  authentication. If not specified, the hostname associated with
  the local IP address of the SSH connection will be used.

- **client_username** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  The local username to use when performing host-based
  authentication. If not specified, the username of the currently
  logged in user will be used.

- **client_keys** ( _see_ [Specifying private keys](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#specifyingprivatekeys)) – (optional)
  A list of keys which will be used to authenticate this client
  via public key authentication. These keys will be used after
  trying keys from a PKCS11 provider or an ssh-agent, if either
  of those are configured. If no client keys are specified,
  an attempt will be made to load them from the files
  `.ssh/id_ed25519_sk`, `.ssh/id_ecdsa_sk`,
  `.ssh/id_ed448`, `.ssh/id_ed25519`,
  `.ssh/id_ecdsa`, `.ssh/id_rsa`, and
  `.ssh/id_dsa` in the user’s home directory, with
  optional certificates loaded from the files
  `.ssh/id_ed25519_sk-cert.pub`,
  `.ssh/id_ecdsa_sk-cert.pub`, `.ssh/id_ed448-cert.pub`,
  `.ssh/id_ed25519-cert.pub`, `.ssh/id_ecdsa-cert.pub`,
  `.ssh/id_rsa-cert.pub`, and `.ssh/id_dsa-cert.pub`.
  If this argument is explicitly set to [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)"), client public key
  authentication will not be performed.

- **client_certs** ( _see_ [Specifying certificates](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#specifyingcertificates)) – (optional)
  A list of optional certificates which can be paired with the
  provided client keys.

- **passphrase** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") or [`bytes`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#bytes "(in Python v3.13)")) –

(optional)
The passphrase to use to decrypt client keys if they are
encrypted, or a [`callable`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#callable "(in Python v3.13)") or coroutine which takes a filename
as a parameter and returns the passphrase to use to decrypt
that file. If not specified, only unencrypted client keys can
be loaded. If the keys passed into client_keys are already
loaded, this argument is ignored.

> Note
>
> A callable or coroutine passed in as a passphrase
> will be called on all filenames configured as
> client keys or client host keys each time an
> SSHClientConnectionOptions object is instantiated,
> even if the keys aren’t encrypted or aren’t ever
> used for authentication.

- **ignore_encrypted** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  Whether or not to ignore encrypted keys when no passphrase is
  specified. This defaults to [`True`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True "(in Python v3.13)") when keys are specified via
  the IdentityFile config option, causing encrypted keys in the
  config to be ignored when no passphrase is specified. Note
  that encrypted keys loaded into an SSH agent can still be used
  when this option is set.

- **host_based_auth** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  Whether or not to allow host-based authentication. By default,
  host-based authentication is enabled if client host keys are
  made available.

- **public_key_auth** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  Whether or not to allow public key authentication. By default,
  public key authentication is enabled if client keys are made
  available.

- **kbdint_auth** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  Whether or not to allow keyboard-interactive authentication. By
  default, keyboard-interactive authentication is enabled if a
  password is specified or if callbacks to respond to challenges
  are made available.

- **password_auth** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  Whether or not to allow password authentication. By default,
  password authentication is enabled if a password is specified
  or if callbacks to provide a password are made available.

- **gss_host** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  The principal name to use for the host in GSS key exchange and
  authentication. If not specified, this value will be the same
  as the `host` argument. If this argument is explicitly set to
  [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)"), GSS key exchange and authentication will not be performed.

- **gss_store** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)"), [`bytes`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#bytes "(in Python v3.13)"), or a [`dict`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#dict "(in Python v3.13)") with [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") or [`bytes`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#bytes "(in Python v3.13)") keys and values) – (optional)
  The GSS credential store from which to acquire credentials.

- **gss_kex** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  Whether or not to allow GSS key exchange. By default, GSS
  key exchange is enabled.

- **gss_auth** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  Whether or not to allow GSS authentication. By default, GSS
  authentication is enabled.

- **gss_delegate_creds** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  Whether or not to forward GSS credentials to the server being
  accessed. By default, GSS credential delegation is disabled.

- **preferred_auth** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") or [`list`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#list "(in Python v3.13)") of [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – A list of authentication methods the client should attempt to
  use in order of preference. By default, the preferred list is
  gssapi-keyex, gssapi-with-mic, hostbased, publickey,
  keyboard-interactive, and then password. This list may be
  limited by which auth methods are implemented by the client
  and which methods the server accepts.

- **disable_trivial_auth** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  Whether or not to allow “trivial” forms of auth where the
  client is not actually challenged for credentials. Setting
  this will cause the connection to fail if a server does not
  perform some non-trivial form of auth during the initial
  SSH handshake. If not specified, all forms of auth supported
  by the server are allowed, including none.

- **agent_path** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  The path of a UNIX domain socket to use to contact an ssh-agent
  process which will perform the operations needed for client
  public key authentication, or the [`SSHServerConnection`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerConnection "asyncssh.SSHServerConnection")
  to use to forward ssh-agent requests over. If this is not
  specified and the environment variable `SSH_AUTH_SOCK` is
  set, its value will be used as the path. If this argument is
  explicitly set to [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)"), an ssh-agent will not be used.

- **agent_identities** ( _see_ [Specifying public keys](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#specifyingpublickeys) and [Specifying certificates](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#specifyingcertificates)) – (optional)
  A list of identities used to restrict which SSH agent keys may
  be used. These may be specified as byte strings in binary SSH
  format or as public keys or certificates ( _see_ [Specifying public keys](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#specifyingpublickeys) and [Specifying certificates](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#specifyingcertificates)).
  If set to [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)"), all keys loaded into the SSH agent will be
  made available for use. This is the default.

- **agent_forwarding** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)") or [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  Whether or not to allow forwarding of ssh-agent requests from
  processes running on the server. This argument can also be set
  to the path of a UNIX domain socket in cases where forwarded
  agent requests should be sent to a different path than client
  agent requests. By default, forwarding ssh-agent requests from
  the server is not allowed.

- **pkcs11_provider** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") or [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  The path of a shared library which should be used as a PKCS#11
  provider for accessing keys on PIV security tokens. By default,
  no local security tokens will be accessed.

- **pkcs11_pin** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) –

(optional)
The PIN to use when accessing security tokens via PKCS#11.

> Note
>
> If your application opens multiple SSH connections
> using PKCS#11 keys, you should consider calling
> [`load_pkcs11_keys()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.load_pkcs11_keys "asyncssh.load_pkcs11_keys") explicitly instead of
> using these arguments. This allows you to pay
> the cost of loading the key information from the
> security tokens only once. You can then pass the
> returned keys via the `client_keys` argument to
> any calls that need them.
>
> Calling [`load_pkcs11_keys()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.load_pkcs11_keys "asyncssh.load_pkcs11_keys") explicitly also
> gives you the ability to load keys from multiple
> tokens with different PINs and to select which
> tokens to load keys from and which keys on those
> tokens to load.

- **client_version** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  An ASCII string to advertise to the SSH server as the version of
  this client, defaulting to `'AsyncSSH'` and its version number.

- **kex_algs** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") or [`list`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#list "(in Python v3.13)") of [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  A list of allowed key exchange algorithms in the SSH handshake,
  taken from [key exchange algorithms](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#kexalgs).

- **encryption_algs** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") or [`list`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#list "(in Python v3.13)") of [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  A list of encryption algorithms to use during the SSH handshake,
  taken from [encryption algorithms](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#encryptionalgs).

- **mac_algs** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") or [`list`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#list "(in Python v3.13)") of [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  A list of MAC algorithms to use during the SSH handshake, taken
  from [MAC algorithms](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#macalgs).

- **compression_algs** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") or [`list`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#list "(in Python v3.13)") of [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  A list of compression algorithms to use during the SSH handshake,
  taken from [compression algorithms](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#compressionalgs), or
  [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)") to disable compression. The client prefers to disable
  compression, but will enable it if the server requires it.

- **signature_algs** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") or [`list`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#list "(in Python v3.13)") of [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  A list of public key signature algorithms to use during the SSH
  handshake, taken from [signature algorithms](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#signaturealgs).

- **rekey_bytes** ( _see_ [Specifying byte counts](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#specifyingbytecounts)) – (optional)
  The number of bytes which can be sent before the SSH session

- **rekey_seconds** ( _see_ [Specifying time intervals](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#specifyingtimeintervals)) – (optional)
  The maximum time in seconds before the SSH session key is
  renegotiated, defaulting to 1 hour.

- **connect_timeout** ( _see_ [Specifying time intervals](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#specifyingtimeintervals)) – (optional)
  The maximum time in seconds allowed to complete an outbound
  SSH connection. This includes the time to establish the TCP
  connection and the time to perform the initial SSH protocol
  handshake, key exchange, and authentication. This is disabled
  by default, relying on the system’s default TCP connect timeout
  and AsyncSSH’s login timeout.

- **login_timeout** ( _see_ [Specifying time intervals](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#specifyingtimeintervals)) –

(optional)
The maximum time in seconds allowed for authentication to
complete, defaulting to 2 minutes. Setting this to 0 will
disable the login timeout.

> Note
>
> This timeout only applies after the SSH TCP
> connection is established. To set a timeout
> which includes establishing the TCP connection,
> use the `connect_timeout` argument above.

- **keepalive_interval** ( _see_ [Specifying time intervals](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#specifyingtimeintervals)) – (optional)
  The time in seconds to wait before sending a keepalive message
  if no data has been received from the server. This defaults to
  0, which disables sending these messages.

- **keepalive_count_max** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  The maximum number of keepalive messages which will be sent
  without getting a response before disconnecting from the
  server. This defaults to 3, but only applies when
  keepalive_interval is non-zero.

- **tcp_keepalive** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  Whether or not to enable keepalive probes at the TCP level to
  detect broken connections, defaulting to [`True`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True "(in Python v3.13)").

- **canonicalize_hostname** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)") or `'always'`) – (optional)
  Whether or not to enable hostname canonicalization, defaulting
  to [`False`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#False "(in Python v3.13)"), in which case hostnames are passed as-is to the
  system resolver. If set to [`True`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True "(in Python v3.13)"), requests that don’t involve

- **canonical_domains** ( [`list`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#list "(in Python v3.13)") of [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  When canonicalize_hostname is set, this specifies list of domain
  suffixes in which to search for the hostname.

- **canonicalize_fallback_local** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  Whether or not to fall back to looking up the hostname against
  the system resolver’s search domains when no matches are found
  in canonical_domains, defaulting to [`True`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True "(in Python v3.13)").

- **canonicalize_max_dots** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  Tha maximum number of dots which can appear in a hostname
  before hostname canonicalization is disabled, defaulting
  to 1. Hostnames with more than this number of dots are
  treated as already being fully qualified and passed as-is
  to the system resolver.

- **canonicalize_permitted_cnames** ( [`list`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#list "(in Python v3.13)") of [`tuple`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#tuple "(in Python v3.13)") of 2 [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") values) – (optional)
  Patterns to match against to decide whether hostname
  canonicalization should return a CNAME. This argument
  contains a list of pairs of wildcard pattern lists. The
  first pattern is matched against the hostname found after
