  If a match can be found in the list for both patterns, the
  CNAME is returned as the canonical hostname. The default
  is an empty list, preventing CNAMEs from being returned.

- **command** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  The default remote command to execute on client sessions.
  An interactive shell is started if no command or subsystem is
  specified.

- **subsystem** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  The default remote subsystem to start on client sessions.

- **env** ( [`dict`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#dict "(in Python v3.13)") with [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") keys and values) –

(optional)
The default environment variables to set for client sessions.
Keys and values passed in here will be converted to Unicode
strings encoded as UTF-8 (ISO 10646) for transmission.

> Note
>
> Many SSH servers restrict which environment
> variables a client is allowed to set. The
> server’s configuration may need to be edited
> before environment variables can be
> successfully set in the remote environment.

- **send_env** ( [`list`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#list "(in Python v3.13)") of [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  A list of environment variable names to pull from
  [`os.environ`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/os.html#os.environ "(in Python v3.13)") and set by default for client sessions. Wildcards
  patterns using `'*'` and `'?'` are allowed, and all variables
  with matching names will be sent with whatever value is set in
  the local environment. If a variable is present in both env
  and send_env, the value from env will be used.

- **request_pty** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)"), `'force'`, or `'auto'`) – (optional)
  Whether or not to request a pseudo-terminal (PTY) by default for
  client sessions. This defaults to [`True`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True "(in Python v3.13)"), which means to request
  a PTY whenever the `term_type` is set. Other possible values
  include [`False`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#False "(in Python v3.13)") to never request a PTY, `'force'` to always
  request a PTY even without `term_type` being set, or `'auto'`
  to request a TTY when `term_type` is set but only when starting
  an interactive shell.

- **term_type** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  The default terminal type to set for client sessions.

- **term_size** ( [`tuple`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#tuple "(in Python v3.13)") of 2 or 4 [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)") values) – (optional)
  The terminal width and height in characters and optionally
  the width and height in pixels to set for client sessions.

- **term_modes** ( [`dict`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#dict "(in Python v3.13)") with [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)") keys and values) – (optional)
  POSIX terminal modes to set for client sessions, where keys are
  taken from [POSIX terminal modes](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#ptymodes) with values
  defined in section 8 of [**RFC 4254**](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc4254.html#section-8).

- **x11_forwarding** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)") or `'ignore_failure'`) – (optional)
  Whether or not to request X11 forwarding for client sessions,
  defaulting to [`False`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#False "(in Python v3.13)"). If set to [`True`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True "(in Python v3.13)"), X11 forwarding will be
  requested and a failure will raise [`ChannelOpenError`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.ChannelOpenError "asyncssh.ChannelOpenError"). It
  can also be set to `'ignore_failure'` to attempt X11 forwarding
  but ignore failures.

- **x11_display** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  The display that X11 connections should be forwarded to,
  defaulting to the value in the environment variable `DISPLAY`.

- **x11_auth_path** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  The path to the Xauthority file to read X11 authentication
  data from, defaulting to the value in the environment variable
  `XAUTHORITY` or the file `.Xauthority` in the user’s
  home directory if that’s not set.

- **x11_single_connection** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  Whether or not to limit X11 forwarding to a single connection,
  defaulting to [`False`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#False "(in Python v3.13)").

- **encoding** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") or [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  The default Unicode encoding to use for data exchanged on client
  sessions.

- **errors** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  The default error handling strategy to apply on Unicode
  encode/decode errors.

- **window** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  The default receive window size to set for client sessions.

- **max_pktsize** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  The default maximum packet size to set for client sessions.

- **config** ( [`list`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#list "(in Python v3.13)") of [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) –

(optional)
Paths to OpenSSH client configuration files to load. This
configuration will be used as a fallback to override the
defaults for settings which are not explicitly specified using
AsyncSSH’s configuration options.

> Note
>
> Specifying configuration files when creating an
> [`SSHClientConnectionOptions`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnectionOptions "asyncssh.SSHClientConnectionOptions") object will
> cause the config file to be read and parsed at
> the time of creation of the object, including
> evaluation of any conditional blocks. If you want
> the config to be parsed for every new connection,
> this argument should be added to the connect or
> listen calls instead. However, if you want to
> save the parsing overhead and your configuration
> doesn’t depend on conditions that would change
> between calls, this argument may be an option.

- **options** ( [`SSHClientConnectionOptions`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnectionOptions "asyncssh.SSHClientConnectionOptions")) – (optional)
  A previous set of options to use as the base to incrementally
  build up a configuration. When an option is not explicitly
  specified, its value will be pulled from this options object
  (if present) before falling back to the default value.

_class_ asyncssh.SSHServerConnectionOptions [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/connection.html#SSHServerConnectionOptions) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerConnectionOptions "Link to this definition")

SSH server connection options

The following options are available to control the acceptance
of SSH server connections:

Parameters:

- **server_factory** ( [`callable`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#callable "(in Python v3.13)") returning [`SSHServer`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServer "asyncssh.SSHServer")) – A [`callable`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#callable "(in Python v3.13)") which returns an [`SSHServer`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServer "asyncssh.SSHServer") object that will
  be created for each new connection.

- **proxy_command** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") or [`list`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#list "(in Python v3.13)") of [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  A string or list of strings specifying a command and arguments
  to run when using [`connect_reverse()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.connect_reverse "asyncssh.connect_reverse") to make a reverse
  direction connection to an SSH client. Data will be forwarded
  to this process over stdin/stdout instead of opening a TCP
  connection. If specified as a string, standard shell quoting
  will be applied when splitting the command and its arguments.

- **server_host_keys** ( _see_ [Specifying private keys](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#specifyingprivatekeys)) – (optional)
  A list of private keys and optional certificates which can be
  used by the server as a host key. Either this argument or
  `gss_host` must be specified. If this is not specified,
  only GSS-based key exchange will be supported.

- **server_host_certs** ( _see_ [Specifying certificates](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#specifyingcertificates)) – (optional)
  A list of optional certificates which can be paired with the
  provided server host keys.

- **send_server_host_keys** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)")) –

(optional)
Whether or not to send a list of the allowed server host keys
for clients to use to update their known hosts like for the
server.

> Note
>
> Enabling this option will allow multiple server
> host keys of the same type to be configured. Only
> the first key of each type will be actively used
> during key exchange, but the others will be
> reported as reserved keys that clients should
> begin to trust, to allow for future key rotation.
> If this option is disabled, specifying multiple
> server host keys of the same type is treated as
> a configuration error.

- **passphrase** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") or [`bytes`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#bytes "(in Python v3.13)")) –

(optional)
The passphrase to use to decrypt server host keys if they are
encrypted, or a [`callable`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#callable "(in Python v3.13)") or coroutine which takes a filename
as a parameter and returns the passphrase to use to decrypt
that file. If not specified, only unencrypted server host keys
can be loaded. If the keys passed into server_host_keys are
already loaded, this argument is ignored.

> Note
>
> A callable or coroutine passed in as a passphrase
> will be called on all filenames configured as
> server host keys each time an
> SSHServerConnectionOptions object is instantiated,
> even if the keys aren’t encrypted or aren’t ever
> used for server validation.

- **known_client_hosts** ( _see_ [Specifying known hosts](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#specifyingknownhosts)) – (optional)
  A list of client hosts which should be trusted to perform
  host-based client authentication. If this is not specified,
  host-based client authentication will be not be performed.

- **trust_client_host** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  Whether or not to use the hostname provided by the client
  when performing host-based authentication. By default, the
  client-provided hostname is not trusted and is instead
  determined by doing a reverse lookup of the IP address the
  client connected from.

- **authorized_client_keys** ( _see_ [Specifying authorized keys](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#specifyingauthorizedkeys)) – (optional)
  A list of authorized user and CA public keys which should be
  trusted for certificate-based client public key authentication.

- **x509_trusted_certs** ( _see_ [Specifying certificates](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#specifyingcertificates)) –

(optional)
A list of certificates which should be trusted for X.509 client
certificate authentication. If this argument is explicitly set
to [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)"), X.509 client certificate authentication will not
be performed.

> Note
>
> X.509 certificates to trust can also be provided
> through an [authorized_keys](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#authorizedkeys)
> file if they are converted into OpenSSH format.
> This allows their trust to be limited to only
> specific client IPs or user names and allows
> SSH functions to be restricted when these
> certificates are used.

- **x509_trusted_cert_paths** ( [`list`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#list "(in Python v3.13)") of [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  A list of path names to “hash directories” containing certificates
  which should be trusted for X.509 client certificate authentication.
  Each certificate should be in a separate file with a name of the
  form _hash.number_, where _hash_ is the OpenSSL hash value of the
  certificate subject name and _number_ is an integer counting up
  from zero if multiple certificates have the same hash.

- **x509_purposes** ( _see_ [Specifying X.509 purposes](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#specifyingx509purposes)) – (optional)
  A list of purposes allowed in the ExtendedKeyUsage of a
  certificate used for X.509 client certificate authentication,
  defulting to ‘secureShellClient’. If this argument is explicitly
  set to [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)"), the client certificate’s ExtendedKeyUsage will
  not be checked.

- **host_based_auth** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  Whether or not to allow host-based authentication. By default,
  host-based authentication is enabled if known client host keys
  are specified or if callbacks to validate client host keys
  are made available.

- **public_key_auth** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  Whether or not to allow public key authentication. By default,
  public key authentication is enabled if authorized client keys
  are specified or if callbacks to validate client keys are made
  available.

- **kbdint_auth** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  Whether or not to allow keyboard-interactive authentication. By
  default, keyboard-interactive authentication is enabled if the
  callbacks to generate challenges are made available.

- **password_auth** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  Whether or not to allow password authentication. By default,
  password authentication is enabled if callbacks to validate a
  password are made available.

- **gss_host** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  The principal name to use for the host in GSS key exchange and
  authentication. If not specified, the value returned by
  [`socket.gethostname()`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/socket.html#socket.gethostname "(in Python v3.13)") will be used if it is a fully qualified
  name. Otherwise, the value used by [`socket.getfqdn()`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/socket.html#socket.getfqdn "(in Python v3.13)") will be
  used. If this argument is explicitly set to [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)"), GSS
  key exchange and authentication will not be performed.

- **gss_store** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)"), [`bytes`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#bytes "(in Python v3.13)"), or a [`dict`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#dict "(in Python v3.13)") with [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") or [`bytes`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#bytes "(in Python v3.13)") keys and values) – (optional)
  The GSS credential store from which to acquire credentials.

- **gss_kex** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  Whether or not to allow GSS key exchange. By default, GSS
  key exchange is enabled.

- **gss_auth** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  Whether or not to allow GSS authentication. By default, GSS
  authentication is enabled.

- **allow_pty** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  Whether or not to allow allocation of a pseudo-tty in sessions,
  defaulting to [`True`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True "(in Python v3.13)")

- **line_editor** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  Whether or not to enable input line editing on sessions which
  have a pseudo-tty allocated, defaulting to [`True`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True "(in Python v3.13)")

- **line_echo** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)")) – (bool)
  Whether or not to echo completed input lines when they are
  entered, rather than waiting for the application to read and
  echo them, defaulting to [`True`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True "(in Python v3.13)"). Setting this to [`False`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#False "(in Python v3.13)")
  and performing the echo in the application can better synchronize
  input and output, especially when there are input prompts.

- **line_history** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – (int)
  The number of lines of input line history to store in the
  line editor when it is enabled, defaulting to 1000

- **max_line_length** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – (int)
  The maximum number of characters allowed in an input line when
  the line editor is enabled, defaulting to 1024

- **rdns_lookup** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  Whether or not to perform reverse DNS lookups on the client’s
  IP address to enable hostname-based matches in authorized key
  file “from” options and “Match Host” config options, defaulting
  to [`False`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#False "(in Python v3.13)").

- **x11_forwarding** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  Whether or not to allow forwarding of X11 connections back
  to the client when the client supports it, defaulting to [`False`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#False "(in Python v3.13)")

- **x11_auth_path** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  The path to the Xauthority file to write X11 authentication
  data to, defaulting to the value in the environment variable
  `XAUTHORITY` or the file `.Xauthority` in the user’s
  home directory if that’s not set

- **agent_forwarding** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  Whether or not to allow forwarding of ssh-agent requests back
  to the client when the client supports it, defaulting to [`True`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True "(in Python v3.13)")

- **process_factory** ( [`callable`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#callable "(in Python v3.13)") or coroutine) – (optional)
  A [`callable`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#callable "(in Python v3.13)") or coroutine handler function which takes an AsyncSSH
  [`SSHServerProcess`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerProcess "asyncssh.SSHServerProcess") argument that will be called each time a
  new shell, exec, or subsystem other than SFTP is requested by the
  client. If set, this takes precedence over the `session_factory`
  argument.

- **session_factory** ( [`callable`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#callable "(in Python v3.13)") or coroutine) – (optional)
  A [`callable`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#callable "(in Python v3.13)") or coroutine handler function which takes AsyncSSH
  stream objects for stdin, stdout, and stderr that will be called
  each time a new shell, exec, or subsystem other than SFTP is
  requested by the client. If not specified, sessions are rejected
  by default unless the [`session_requested()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServer.session_requested "asyncssh.SSHServer.session_requested") method is overridden on the
  [`SSHServer`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServer "asyncssh.SSHServer") object returned by `server_factory` to make
  this decision.

- **encoding** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") or [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  The Unicode encoding to use for data exchanged on sessions on
  this server, defaulting to UTF-8 (ISO 10646) format. If [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)")
  is passed in, the application can send and receive raw bytes.

- **errors** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  The error handling strategy to apply on Unicode encode/decode
  errors of data exchanged on sessions on this server, defaulting
  to ‘strict’.

- **sftp_factory** ( [`callable`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#callable "(in Python v3.13)") or coroutine) – (optional)
  A [`callable`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#callable "(in Python v3.13)") or coroutine which returns an [`SFTPServer`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SFTPServer "asyncssh.SFTPServer")
  object that will be created each time an SFTP session is
  requested by the client, or [`True`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True "(in Python v3.13)") to use the base
  [`SFTPServer`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SFTPServer "asyncssh.SFTPServer") class to handle SFTP requests. If not
  specified, SFTP sessions are rejected by default.

- **sftp_version** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  The maximum version of the SFTP protocol to support, currently
  either 3 or 4, defaulting to 3.

- **allow_scp** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  Whether or not to allow incoming scp requests to be accepted.
  This option can only be used in conjunction with `sftp_factory`.
  If not specified, scp requests will be passed as regular
  commands to the `process_factory` or `session_factory`.
  to the client when the client supports it, defaulting to [`True`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True "(in Python v3.13)")

- **window** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  The receive window size for sessions on this server

- **max_pktsize** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  The maximum packet size for sessions on this server

- **server_version** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  An ASCII string to advertise to SSH clients as the version of
  this server, defaulting to `'AsyncSSH'` and its version number.

- **kex_algs** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") or [`list`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#list "(in Python v3.13)") of [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  A list of allowed key exchange algorithms in the SSH handshake,
  taken from [key exchange algorithms](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#kexalgs),

- **encryption_algs** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") or [`list`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#list "(in Python v3.13)") of [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  A list of encryption algorithms to use during the SSH handshake,
  taken from [encryption algorithms](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#encryptionalgs).

- **mac_algs** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") or [`list`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#list "(in Python v3.13)") of [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  A list of MAC algorithms to use during the SSH handshake, taken
  from [MAC algorithms](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#macalgs).

- **compression_algs** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") or [`list`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#list "(in Python v3.13)") of [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  A list of compression algorithms to use during the SSH handshake,
  taken from [compression algorithms](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#compressionalgs), or
  [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)") to disable compression. The server defaults to allowing
  either no compression or compression after auth, depending on
  what the client requests.

- **signature_algs** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") or [`list`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#list "(in Python v3.13)") of [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  A list of public key signature algorithms to use during the SSH
  handshake, taken from [signature algorithms](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#signaturealgs).

- **rekey_bytes** ( _see_ [Specifying byte counts](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#specifyingbytecounts)) – (optional)
  The number of bytes which can be sent before the SSH session
  key is renegotiated, defaulting to 1 GB.

- **rekey_seconds** ( _see_ [Specifying time intervals](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#specifyingtimeintervals)) – (optional)
  The maximum time in seconds before the SSH session key is
  renegotiated, defaulting to 1 hour.

- **connect_timeout** ( _see_ [Specifying time intervals](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#specifyingtimeintervals)) – (optional)
  The maximum time in seconds allowed to complete an outbound
  SSH connection. This includes the time to establish the TCP
  connection and the time to perform the initial SSH protocol
  handshake, key exchange, and authentication. This is disabled
  by default, relying on the system’s default TCP connect timeout
  and AsyncSSH’s login timeout.

- **login_timeout** ( _see_ [Specifying time intervals](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#specifyingtimeintervals)) –

(optional)
The maximum time in seconds allowed for authentication to
complete, defaulting to 2 minutes. Setting this to 0 will
disable the login timeout.

> Note
>
> This timeout only applies after the SSH TCP
> connection is established. To set a timeout
> which includes establishing the TCP connection,
> use the `connect_timeout` argument above.

- **keepalive_interval** ( _see_ [Specifying time intervals](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#specifyingtimeintervals)) – (optional)
  The time in seconds to wait before sending a keepalive message
  if no data has been received from the client. This defaults to
  0, which disables sending these messages.

- **keepalive_count_max** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  The maximum number of keepalive messages which will be sent
  without getting a response before disconnecting a client.
  This defaults to 3, but only applies when keepalive_interval is
  non-zero.

- **tcp_keepalive** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  Whether or not to enable keepalive probes at the TCP level to
  detect broken connections, defaulting to [`True`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True "(in Python v3.13)").

- **canonicalize_hostname** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)") or `'always'`) – (optional)
  Whether or not to enable hostname canonicalization, defaulting
  to [`False`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#False "(in Python v3.13)"), in which case hostnames are passed as-is to the
  system resolver. If set to [`True`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True "(in Python v3.13)"), requests that don’t involve
  a proxy tunnel or command will attempt to canonicalize the hostname
  using canonical_domains and rules in canonicalize_permitted_cnames.
  If set to `'always'`, hostname canonicalization is also applied
  to proxied requests.

- **canonical_domains** ( [`list`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#list "(in Python v3.13)") of [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  When canonicalize_hostname is set, this specifies list of domain
  suffixes in which to search for the hostname.

- **canonicalize_fallback_local** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  Whether or not to fall back to looking up the hostname against
  the system resolver’s search domains when no matches are found
  in canonical_domains, defaulting to [`True`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True "(in Python v3.13)").

- **canonicalize_max_dots** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  Tha maximum number of dots which can appear in a hostname
  before hostname canonicalization is disabled, defaulting
  to 1. Hostnames with more than this number of dots are
  treated as already being fully qualified and passed as-is
  to the system resolver.

- **config** ( [`list`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#list "(in Python v3.13)") of [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) –

(optional)
Paths to OpenSSH server configuration files to load. This
configuration will be used as a fallback to override the
defaults for settings which are not explicitly specified using
AsyncSSH’s configuration options.

> Note
>
> Specifying configuration files when creating an
> [`SSHServerConnectionOptions`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerConnectionOptions "asyncssh.SSHServerConnectionOptions") object will
> cause the config file to be read and parsed at
> the time of creation of the object, including
> evaluation of any conditional blocks. If you want
> the config to be parsed for every new connection,
> this argument should be added to the connect or
> listen calls instead. However, if you want to
> save the parsing overhead and your configuration
> doesn’t depend on conditions that would change
> between calls, this argument may be an option.

- **options** ( [`SSHServerConnectionOptions`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerConnectionOptions "asyncssh.SSHServerConnectionOptions")) – (optional)
  A previous set of options to use as the base to incrementally
  build up a configuration. When an option is not explicitly
  specified, its value will be pulled from this options object
  (if present) before falling back to the default value.

| _async_ wait( _check=False_, _timeout=None_) [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/process.html#SSHClientProcess.wait) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientProcess.wait "Link to this definition")<br>Wait for process to exit<br>This method is a coroutine which waits for the process to<br>exit. It returns an [`SSHCompletedProcess`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHCompletedProcess "asyncssh.SSHCompletedProcess") object with<br>the exit status or signal information and the output sent<br>to stdout and stderr if those are redirected to pipes.<br>If the check argument is set to [`True`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True "(in Python v3.13)"), a non-zero exit<br>status from the process with trigger the [`ProcessError`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.ProcessError "asyncssh.ProcessError")<br>exception to be raised.<br>If a timeout is specified and it expires before the process<br>exits, the [`TimeoutError`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.TimeoutError "asyncssh.TimeoutError") exception will be raised. By<br>default, no timeout is set and this call will wait indefinitely.<br>Parameters:<br>- **check** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)")) – Whether or not to raise an error on non-zero exit status<br> <br>- **timeout** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)"), [`float`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#float "(in Python v3.13)"), or [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)")) – Amount of time in seconds to wait for process to exit, or<br> [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)") to wait indefinitely<br> <br>Returns:<br>[`SSHCompletedProcess`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHCompletedProcess "asyncssh.SSHCompletedProcess")<br>Raises:<br>[`ProcessError`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.ProcessError "asyncssh.ProcessError") if check is set to [`True`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True "(in Python v3.13)")<br>and the process returns a non-zero exit status<br>[`TimeoutError`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.TimeoutError "asyncssh.TimeoutError") if the timeout expires<br>before the process exits | _async_ redirect( _stdin=None_, _stdout=None_, _stderr=None_, _bufsize=8192_, _send_eof=True_, _recv_eof=True_) [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/process.html#SSHServerProcess.redirect) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerProcess.redirect "Link to this definition")<br>Perform I/O redirection for the process<br>This method redirects data going to or from any or all of<br>standard input, standard output, and standard error for<br>the process.<br>The [`stdin`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerProcess.stdin "asyncssh.SSHServerProcess.stdin") argument can be any of the following:<br>> - An [`SSHWriter`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHWriter "asyncssh.SSHWriter") object<br>> <br>> - An [`asyncio.StreamWriter`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/asyncio-stream.html#asyncio.StreamWriter "(in Python v3.13)") object<br>> <br>> - A file object open for write<br>> <br>> - An [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)") file descriptor open for write<br>> <br>> - A connected socket object<br>> <br>> - A string or [`PurePath`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/pathlib.html#pathlib.PurePath "(in Python v3.13)") containing<br>> the name of a file or device to open<br>> <br>> - `DEVNULL` to discard standard error output<br>> <br>> - `PIPE` to interactively read standard error output<br>The [`stdout`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerProcess.stdout "asyncssh.SSHServerProcess.stdout") and [`stderr`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerProcess.stderr "asyncssh.SSHServerProcess.stderr") arguments can be any of the following:<br>> - An [`SSHReader`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHReader "asyncssh.SSHReader") object<br>> <br>> - An [`asyncio.StreamReader`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/asyncio-stream.html#asyncio.StreamReader "(in Python v3.13)") object<br>> <br>> - A file object open for read<br>> <br>> - An [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)") file descriptor open for read<br>> <br>> - A connected socket object<br>> <br>> - A string or [`PurePath`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/pathlib.html#pathlib.PurePath "(in Python v3.13)") containing<br>> the name of a file or device to open<br>> <br>> - `DEVNULL` to provide no input to standard input<br>> <br>> - `PIPE` to interactively write standard input<br>File objects passed in can be associated with plain files, pipes,<br>sockets, or ttys.<br>The default value of [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)") means to not change redirection<br>for that stream.<br>Note<br>When passing in asyncio streams, it is the responsibility<br>of the caller to close the associated transport when it<br>is no longer needed.<br>Parameters:<br>- **stdin** – Target to feed data from standard input to<br> <br>- **stdout** – Source of data to feed to standard output<br> <br>- **stderr** – Source of data to feed to standard error<br> <br>- **bufsize** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – Buffer size to use when forwarding data from a file<br> <br>- **send_eof** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)")) – Whether or not to send EOF to the channel when EOF is<br> received from stdout or stderr, defaulting to [`True`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True "(in Python v3.13)"). If<br> set to [`False`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#False "(in Python v3.13)"), the channel will remain open after EOF is<br> received on stdout or stderr, and multiple sources can be<br> redirected to the channel.<br> <br>- **recv_eof** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)")) – Whether or not to send EOF to stdin when EOF is received<br> on the channel, defaulting to [`True`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True "(in Python v3.13)"). If set to [`False`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#False "(in Python v3.13)"),<br> the redirect target of stdin will remain open after EOF<br> is received on the channel and can be used for multiple<br> redirects. |     |

_class_ asyncssh.SSHCompletedProcess [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/process.html#SSHCompletedProcess) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHCompletedProcess "Link to this definition")

Results from running an SSH process

This object is returned by the [`run`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.run "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.run")
method on [`SSHClientConnection`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection") when the requested command
has finished running. It contains the following fields:

> | Field       | Description                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       | Type                                                                                                                                                                        |
> | ----------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
> | env         | The environment the client requested<br>to be set for the process                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 | [`dict`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#dict "(in Python v3.13)") or [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)")   |
> | command     | The command the client requested the<br>process to execute (if any)                                                                                                                                                                                                                               | [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") or [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)")     |
> | subsystem   | The subsystem the client requested the<br>process to open (if any)                                                                                                                                                                                                                                | [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") or [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)")     |
> | exit_status | The exit status returned, or -1 if an<br>exit signal is sent                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      | [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")                                                                                           |

_class_ asyncssh.SSHSubprocessProtocol [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/subprocess.html#SSHSubprocessProtocol) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHSubprocessProtocol "Link to this definition")

SSH subprocess protocol

This class conforms to [`asyncio.SubprocessProtocol`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/asyncio-protocol.html#asyncio.SubprocessProtocol "(in Python v3.13)"), but with
the following enhancement:

> - If encoding is set when the subprocess is created, all data
>   passed to [`pipe_data_received()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHSubprocessProtocol.pipe_data_received "asyncssh.SSHSubprocessProtocol.pipe_data_received") will be string values
>   containing Unicode data. However, for compatibility with
>   [`asyncio.SubprocessProtocol`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/asyncio-protocol.html#asyncio.SubprocessProtocol "(in Python v3.13)"), encoding defaults to
>   [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)"), in which case all data is delivered as bytes.

| General subprocess protocol handlers                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      |     |
| ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | --- |
| connection_made( _transport_) [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/subprocess.html#SSHSubprocessProtocol.connection_made) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHSubprocessProtocol.connection_made "Link to this definition")<br>Called when a remote process is successfully started<br>This method is called when a remote process is successfully<br>started. The transport parameter should be stored if needed<br>for later use.<br>Parameters:<br>**transport** ( [`SSHSubprocessTransport`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHSubprocessTransport "asyncssh.SSHSubprocessTransport")) – The transport to use to communicate with the remote process.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 |     |
| pipe_connection_lost( _fd_, _exc_) [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/subprocess.html#SSHSubprocessProtocol.pipe_connection_lost) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHSubprocessProtocol.pipe_connection_lost "Link to this definition")<br>Called when the pipe to a remote process is closed<br>This method is called when a pipe to a remote process is<br>closed. If the channel is shut down cleanly, _exc_ will be<br>[`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)"). Otherwise, it will be an exception explaining the<br>reason the pipe was closed.<br>Parameters:<br>- **fd** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – The integer file descriptor of the pipe which was<br> closed. This will be 1 for stdout or 2 for stderr.<br> <br>- **exc** ( [`Exception`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/exceptions.html#Exception "(in Python v3.13)") or [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)")) – The exception which caused the channel to close, or<br> [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)") if the channel closed cleanly. |     |

| Subprocess protocol read handlers                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            |     |
| ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | --- |
| pipe_data_received( _fd_, _data_) [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/subprocess.html#SSHSubprocessProtocol.pipe_data_received) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHSubprocessProtocol.pipe_data_received "Link to this definition")<br>Called when data is received from the remote process<br>This method is called when data is received from the remote<br>process. If an encoding was specified when the process was<br>started, the data will be delivered as a string after decoding<br>with the requested encoding. Otherwise, the data will be<br>delivered as bytes.<br>Parameters:<br>- **fd** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – The integer file descriptor of the pipe data was received<br> on. This will be 1 for stdout or 2 for stderr.<br> <br>- **data** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") or [`bytes`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#bytes "(in Python v3.13)")) – The data received from the remote process |     |

_class_ asyncssh.SSHSubprocessTransport( _protocol_factory_) [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/subprocess.html#SSHSubprocessTransport) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHSubprocessTransport "Link to this definition")

SSH subprocess transport

This class conforms to [`asyncio.SubprocessTransport`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/asyncio-protocol.html#asyncio.SubprocessTransport "(in Python v3.13)"), but with
the following enhancements:

> - All functionality available through [`SSHClientProcess`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientProcess "asyncssh.SSHClientProcess")
>   is also available here, such as the ability to dynamically
>   redirect stdin, stdout, and stderr at any time during the
>   lifetime of the process.
>
> - If encoding is set when the subprocess is created, all data
>   written to the transports created by [`get_pipe_transport()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHSubprocessTransport.get_pipe_transport "asyncssh.SSHSubprocessTransport.get_pipe_transport")
>   should be strings containing Unicode data. The encoding defaults
>   to [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)"), though, to preserve compatibility with
>   [`asyncio.SubprocessTransport`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/asyncio-protocol.html#asyncio.SubprocessTransport "(in Python v3.13)"), which expects data
>   to be written as bytes.

| General subprocess transport methods                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             |     |
| ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | --- |
| get_extra_info( _name_, _default=None_) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHSubprocessTransport.get_extra_info "Link to this definition")<br>Return additional information about this process<br>This method returns extra information about the channel<br>associated with this process. See [`get_extra_info()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientChannel.get_extra_info "asyncssh.SSHClientChannel.get_extra_info") on [`SSHClientChannel`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientChannel "asyncssh.SSHClientChannel")<br>for additional information.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       |     |
| get_pid() [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/subprocess.html#SSHSubprocessTransport.get_pid) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHSubprocessTransport.get_pid "Link to this definition")<br>Return the PID of the remote process<br>This method always returns [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)"), since SSH doesn’t report<br>remote PIDs.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 |     |
| get_pipe_transport( _fd_) [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/subprocess.html#SSHSubprocessTransport.get_pipe_transport) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHSubprocessTransport.get_pipe_transport "Link to this definition")<br>Return a transport for the requested stream<br>Parameters:<br>**fd** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – The integer file descriptor (0-2) to return the transport for,<br>where 0 means stdin, 1 means stdout, and 2 means stderr.<br>Returns:<br>an [`SSHSubprocessReadPipe`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHSubprocessReadPipe "asyncssh.SSHSubprocessReadPipe") or<br>[`SSHSubprocessWritePipe`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHSubprocessWritePipe "asyncssh.SSHSubprocessWritePipe")                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              |     |
| get_returncode() [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/subprocess.html#SSHSubprocessTransport.get_returncode) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHSubprocessTransport.get_returncode "Link to this definition")<br>Return the exit status or signal for the remote process<br>This method returns the exit status of the session if one has<br>been sent. If an exit signal was sent, this method returns<br>the negative of the numeric value of that signal, matching<br>the behavior of [`asyncio.SubprocessTransport.get_returncode()`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/asyncio-protocol.html#asyncio.SubprocessTransport.get_returncode "(in Python v3.13)").<br>If neither has been sent, this method returns [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)").<br>Returns:<br>[`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)") or [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)")                                                                                             |     |
| change_terminal_size( _width_, _height_, _pixwidth=0_, _pixheight=0_) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHSubprocessTransport.change_terminal_size "Link to this definition")<br>Change the terminal window size for this process<br>This method changes the width and height of the terminal<br>associated with this process.<br>Parameters:<br>- **width** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – The width of the terminal in characters<br> <br>- **height** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – The height of the terminal in characters<br> <br>- **pixwidth** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> The width of the terminal in pixels<br> <br>- **pixheight** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> The height of the terminal in pixels<br> <br>Raises:<br>[`OSError`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/exceptions.html#OSError "(in Python v3.13)") if the SSH channel is not open |     |

## Session Classes [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#session-classes "Link to this heading")

_class_ asyncssh.SSHClientSession [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/session.html#SSHClientSession) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientSession "Link to this definition")

SSH client session handler

Applications should subclass this when implementing an SSH client
session handler. The functions listed below should be implemented
to define application-specific behavior. In particular, the standard
[`asyncio`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/asyncio.html#module-asyncio "(in Python v3.13)") protocol methods such as [`connection_made()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientSession.connection_made "asyncssh.SSHClientSession.connection_made"),
[`connection_lost()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientSession.connection_lost "asyncssh.SSHClientSession.connection_lost"), [`data_received()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientSession.data_received "asyncssh.SSHClientSession.data_received"), [`eof_received()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientSession.eof_received "asyncssh.SSHClientSession.eof_received"),
[`pause_writing()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientSession.pause_writing "asyncssh.SSHClientSession.pause_writing"), and [`resume_writing()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientSession.resume_writing "asyncssh.SSHClientSession.resume_writing") are all supported.
In addition, [`session_started()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientSession.session_started "asyncssh.SSHClientSession.session_started") is called as soon as the SSH
session is fully started, [`xon_xoff_requested()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientSession.xon_xoff_requested "asyncssh.SSHClientSession.xon_xoff_requested") can be used to
determine if the server wants the client to support XON/XOFF flow
control, and [`exit_status_received()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientSession.exit_status_received "asyncssh.SSHClientSession.exit_status_received") and
[`exit_signal_received()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientSession.exit_signal_received "asyncssh.SSHClientSession.exit_signal_received") can be used to receive session exit
information.

_class_ asyncssh.SSHServerSession [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/session.html#SSHServerSession) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerSession "Link to this definition")

SSH server session handler

Applications should subclass this when implementing an SSH server
session handler. The functions listed below should be implemented
to define application-specific behavior. In particular, the
standard [`asyncio`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/asyncio.html#module-asyncio "(in Python v3.13)") protocol methods such as [`connection_made()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerSession.connection_made "asyncssh.SSHServerSession.connection_made"),
[`connection_lost()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerSession.connection_lost "asyncssh.SSHServerSession.connection_lost"), [`data_received()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerSession.data_received "asyncssh.SSHServerSession.data_received"), [`eof_received()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerSession.eof_received "asyncssh.SSHServerSession.eof_received"),
[`pause_writing()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerSession.pause_writing "asyncssh.SSHServerSession.pause_writing"), and [`resume_writing()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerSession.resume_writing "asyncssh.SSHServerSession.resume_writing") are all supported.
In addition, [`pty_requested()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerSession.pty_requested "asyncssh.SSHServerSession.pty_requested") is called when the client requests a
pseudo-terminal, one of [`shell_requested()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerSession.shell_requested "asyncssh.SSHServerSession.shell_requested"), [`exec_requested()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerSession.exec_requested "asyncssh.SSHServerSession.exec_requested"),
or [`subsystem_requested()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerSession.subsystem_requested "asyncssh.SSHServerSession.subsystem_requested") is called depending on what type of
session the client wants to start, [`session_started()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerSession.session_started "asyncssh.SSHServerSession.session_started") is called
once the SSH session is fully started, [`terminal_size_changed()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerSession.terminal_size_changed "asyncssh.SSHServerSession.terminal_size_changed") is
called when the client’s terminal size changes, [`signal_received()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerSession.signal_received "asyncssh.SSHServerSession.signal_received")
is called when the client sends a signal, and [`break_received()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerSession.break_received "asyncssh.SSHServerSession.break_received")
is called when the client sends a break.

_class_ asyncssh.SSHTCPSession [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/session.html#SSHTCPSession) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHTCPSession "Link to this definition")

SSH TCP session handler

Applications should subclass this when implementing a handler for
SSH direct or forwarded TCP connections.

SSH client applications wishing to open a direct connection should call
[`create_connection()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.create_connection "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.create_connection")
on their [`SSHClientConnection`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection"), passing in a factory which
returns instances of this class.

Server applications wishing to allow direct connections should
implement the coroutine [`connection_requested()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServer.connection_requested "asyncssh.SSHServer.connection_requested") on their [`SSHServer`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServer "asyncssh.SSHServer")
object and have it return instances of this class.

Server applications wishing to allow connection forwarding back
to the client should implement the coroutine [`server_requested()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServer.server_requested "asyncssh.SSHServer.server_requested") on their [`SSHServer`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServer "asyncssh.SSHServer") object
and call [`create_connection()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerConnection.create_connection "asyncssh.SSHServerConnection.create_connection") on their
[`SSHServerConnection`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerConnection "asyncssh.SSHServerConnection") for each new connection, passing it a
factory which returns instances of this class.

When a connection is successfully opened, [`session_started()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHTCPSession.session_started "asyncssh.SSHTCPSession.session_started")
will be called, after which the application can begin sending data.
Received data will be passed to the [`data_received()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHTCPSession.data_received "asyncssh.SSHTCPSession.data_received") method.

The<br>channel parameter should be stored if needed for later use.<br>Parameters:<br>**chan** ( [`SSHTCPChannel`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHTCPChannel "asyncssh.SSHTCPChannel")) – The channel which was successfully opened.                                                                                                                   |     |
| connection_lost( _exc_) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHTCPSession.connection_lost "Link to this definition")<br>Called when a channel is closed<br>This method is called when a channel is closed. If the channel<br>is shut down cleanly, _exc_ will be [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)"). Otherwise, it<br>will be an exception explaining the reason for the channel close.<br>Parameters:<br>**exc** ( [`Exception`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/exceptions.html#Exception "(in Python v3.13)")) – The exception which caused the channel to close, or<br>[`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)") if the channel closed cleanly. |     |
| session_started() [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHTCPSession.session_started "Link to this definition")<br>Called when the session is started<br>This method is called when a session has started up. For<br>client and server sessions, this will be called once a<br>shell, exec, or subsystem request has been successfully<br>completed. For TCP and UNIX domain socket sessions, it will<br>be called immediately after the connection is opened.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    |     |

| General session read handlers                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               |     |
| ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | --- |
| data_received( _data_, _datatype_) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHTCPSession.data_received "Link to this definition")<br>Called when data is received on the channel<br>This method is called when data is received on the channel.<br>If an encoding was specified when the channel was created,<br>the data will be delivered as a string after decoding with<br>the requested encoding. Otherwise, the data will be delivered<br>as bytes.<br>Parameters:<br>- **data** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") or [`bytes`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#bytes "(in Python v3.13)")) – The data received on the channel<br> <br>- **datatype** – The extended data type of the data, from [extended\<br> data types](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#extendeddatatypes)            |     |
| eof_received() [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHTCPSession.eof_received "Link to this definition")<br>Called when EOF is received on the channel<br>This method is called when an end-of-file indication is received<br>on the channel, after which no more data will be received. If this<br>method returns [`True`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True "(in Python v3.13)"), the channel remains half open and data<br>may still be sent. Otherwise, the channel is automatically closed<br>after this method returns. This is the default behavior for<br>classes derived directly from `SSHSession`, but not when<br>using the higher-level streams API. Because input is buffered<br>in that case, streaming sessions enable half-open channels to<br>allow applications to respond to input read after an end-of-file<br>indication is received. |     |

While data can still be buffered locally,<br>applications may wish to stop producing new data until the<br>write buffer has drained. |     |
| resume_writing() [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHTCPSession.resume_writing "Link to this definition")<br>Called when the write buffer has sufficiently drained<br>This method is called when the channel’s send window reopens<br>and enough data has drained from the write buffer to allow the<br>application to produce more data.                                                                                                      |     |

_class_ asyncssh.SSHUNIXSession [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/session.html#SSHUNIXSession) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHUNIXSession "Link to this definition")

SSH UNIX domain socket session handler

Applications should subclass this when implementing a handler for
SSH direct or forwarded UNIX domain socket connections.

SSH client applications wishing to open a direct connection should call
[`create_unix_connection()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.create_unix_connection "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.create_unix_connection") on their
[`SSHClientConnection`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection"), passing in a factory which returns
instances of this class.

Server applications wishing to allow direct connections should
implement the coroutine [`unix_connection_requested()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServer.unix_connection_requested "asyncssh.SSHServer.unix_connection_requested") on their [`SSHServer`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServer "asyncssh.SSHServer")
object and have it return instances of this class.

Server applications wishing to allow connection forwarding back
to the client should implement the coroutine
[`unix_server_requested()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServer.unix_server_requested "asyncssh.SSHServer.unix_server_requested")
on their [`SSHServer`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServer "asyncssh.SSHServer") object and call
[`create_unix_connection()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerConnection.create_unix_connection "asyncssh.SSHServerConnection.create_unix_connection") on their
[`SSHServerConnection`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerConnection "asyncssh.SSHServerConnection") for each new connection, passing it a
factory which returns instances of this class.

When a connection is successfully opened, [`session_started()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHUNIXSession.session_started "asyncssh.SSHUNIXSession.session_started")
will be called, after which the application can begin sending data.
Received data will be passed to the [`data_received()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHUNIXSession.data_received "asyncssh.SSHUNIXSession.data_received") method.
