| get_extra_info( _name_, _default=None_) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHTCPChannel.get_extra_info "Link to this definition")<br>Get additional information about the channel<br>This method returns extra information about the channel once<br>it is established. Supported values include `'connection'`<br>to return the SSH connection this channel is running over plus<br>all of the values supported on that connection.<br>For TCP channels, the values `'local_peername'` and<br>`'remote_peername'` are added to return the local and remote<br>host and port information for the tunneled TCP connection.<br>For UNIX channels, the values `'local_peername'` and<br>`'remote_peername'` are added to return the local and remote<br>path information for the tunneled UNIX domain socket connection.<br>Since UNIX domain sockets provide no “source” address, only<br>one of these will be filled in.<br>See [`get_extra_info()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.get_extra_info "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.get_extra_info")<br>on [`SSHClientConnection`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection") for more information.<br>Additional information stored on the channel by calling<br>[`set_extra_info()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHTCPChannel.set_extra_info "asyncssh.SSHTCPChannel.set_extra_info") can also be returned here. |     |
| set_extra_info( _\*\*kwargs_) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHTCPChannel.set_extra_info "Link to this definition")<br>Store additional information associated with the channel<br>This method allows extra information to be associated with the<br>channel. The information to store should be passed in as<br>keyword parameters and can later be returned by calling<br>[`get_extra_info()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHTCPChannel.get_extra_info "asyncssh.SSHTCPChannel.get_extra_info") with one of the keywords as the name<br>to retrieve.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           |     |

| General channel read methods                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           |     |
| -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | --- |
| pause_reading() [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHTCPChannel.pause_reading "Link to this definition")<br>Pause delivery of incoming data<br>This method is used to temporarily suspend delivery of incoming<br>channel data. After this call, incoming data will no longer<br>be delivered until [`resume_reading()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHTCPChannel.resume_reading "asyncssh.SSHTCPChannel.resume_reading") is called. Data will be<br>buffered locally up to the configured SSH channel window size,<br>but window updates will no longer be sent, eventually causing<br>back pressure on the remote system.<br>Note<br>Channel close notifications are not suspended by this<br>call. If the remote system closes the channel while<br>delivery is suspended, the channel will be closed even<br>though some buffered data may not have been delivered. |     |
| resume_reading() [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHTCPChannel.resume_reading "Link to this definition")<br>Resume delivery of incoming data<br>This method can be called to resume delivery of incoming data<br>which was suspended by a call to [`pause_reading()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHTCPChannel.pause_reading "asyncssh.SSHTCPChannel.pause_reading"). As soon<br>as this method is called, any buffered data will be delivered<br>immediately. A pending end-of-file notification may also be<br>delivered if one was queued while reading was paused.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                |     |

| General channel write methods                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       |     |
| --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | --- |
| can_write_eof() [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHTCPChannel.can_write_eof "Link to this definition")<br>Return whether the channel supports [`write_eof()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHTCPChannel.write_eof "asyncssh.SSHTCPChannel.write_eof")<br>This method always returns [`True`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True "(in Python v3.13)").                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            |     |
| get_write_buffer_size() [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHTCPChannel.get_write_buffer_size "Link to this definition")<br>Return the current size of the channel’s output buffer<br>This method returns how many bytes are currently in the<br>channel’s output buffer waiting to be written.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       |     |
| set_write_buffer_limits( _high=None_, _low=None_) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHTCPChannel.set_write_buffer_limits "Link to this definition")<br>Set the high- and low-water limits for write flow control<br>This method sets the limits used when deciding when to call<br>the [`pause_writing()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientSession.pause_writing "asyncssh.SSHClientSession.pause_writing")<br>and [`resume_writing()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientSession.resume_writing "asyncssh.SSHClientSession.resume_writing")<br>methods on SSH sessions. Writing will be paused when the write<br>buffer size exceeds the high-water mark, and resumed when the<br>write buffer size equals or drops below the low-water mark.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               |     |
| write( _data_, _datatype=None_) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHTCPChannel.write "Link to this definition")<br>Write data on the channel<br>This method can be called to send data on the channel. If<br>an encoding was specified when the channel was created, the<br>data should be provided as a string and will be converted<br>using that encoding. Otherwise, the data should be provided<br>as bytes.<br>An extended data type can optionally be provided. For<br>instance, this is used from a [`SSHServerSession`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerSession "asyncssh.SSHServerSession")<br>to write data to `stderr`.<br>Parameters:<br>- **data** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") or [`bytes`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#bytes "(in Python v3.13)")) – The data to send on the channel<br> <br>- **datatype** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> The extended data type of the data, from [extended\<br> data types](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#extendeddatatypes)<br> <br>Raises:<br>[`OSError`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/exceptions.html#OSError "(in Python v3.13)") if the channel isn’t open for sending<br>or the extended data type is not valid for this type<br>of channel |     |
| writelines( _list_of_data_, _datatype=None_) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHTCPChannel.writelines "Link to this definition")<br>Write a list of data bytes on the channel<br>This method can be called to write a list (or any iterable) of<br>data bytes to the channel. It is functionality equivalent to<br>calling [`write()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHTCPChannel.write "asyncssh.SSHTCPChannel.write") on each element in the list.<br>Parameters:<br>- **list_of_data** (iterable of [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") or [`bytes`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#bytes "(in Python v3.13)")) – The data to send on the channel<br> <br>- **datatype** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> The extended data type of the data, from [extended\<br> data types](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#extendeddatatypes)<br> <br>Raises:<br>[`OSError`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/exceptions.html#OSError "(in Python v3.13)") if the channel isn’t open for sending<br>or the extended data type is not valid for this type<br>of channel                                                                                                                                                                  |     |
| write_eof() [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHTCPChannel.write_eof "Link to this definition")<br>Write EOF on the channel<br>This method sends an end-of-file indication on the<br>channel, after which no more data can be sent. The<br>channel remains open, though, and data may still be<br>sent in the other direction.<br>Raises:<br>[`OSError`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/exceptions.html#OSError "(in Python v3.13)") if the channel isn’t open for sending                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        |     |

Supported values include `'connection'`<br>to return the SSH connection this channel is running over plus<br>all of the values supported on that connection.<br>For TCP channels, the values `'local_peername'` and<br>`'remote_peername'` are added to return the local and remote<br>host and port information for the tunneled TCP connection.<br>For UNIX channels, the values `'local_peername'` and<br>`'remote_peername'` are added to return the local and remote<br>path information for the tunneled UNIX domain socket connection.<br>Since UNIX domain sockets provide no “source” address, only<br>one of these will be filled in.<br>See [`get_extra_info()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.get_extra_info "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.get_extra_info")<br>on [`SSHClientConnection`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection") for more information.<br>Additional information stored on the channel by calling<br>[`set_extra_info()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHTunTapChannel.set_extra_info "asyncssh.SSHTunTapChannel.set_extra_info") can also be returned here. |     |

| pause_reading() [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHTunTapChannel.pause_reading "Link to this definition")<br>Pause delivery of incoming data<br>This method is used to temporarily suspend delivery of incoming<br>channel data. After this call, incoming data will no longer<br>be delivered until [`resume_reading()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHTunTapChannel.resume_reading "asyncssh.SSHTunTapChannel.resume_reading") is called. Data will be<br>buffered locally up to the configured SSH channel window size,<br>but window updates will no longer be sent, eventually causing<br>back pressure on the remote system.<br>Note<br>Channel close notifications are not suspended by this<br>call. If the remote system closes the channel while<br>delivery is suspended, the channel will be closed even<br>though some buffered data may not have been delivered. |     |
| resume_reading() [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHTunTapChannel.resume_reading "Link to this definition")<br>Resume delivery of incoming data<br>This method can be called to resume delivery of incoming data<br>which was suspended by a call to [`pause_reading()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHTunTapChannel.pause_reading "asyncssh.SSHTunTapChannel.pause_reading"). As soon<br>as this method is called, any buffered data will be delivered<br>immediately. A pending end-of-file notification may also be<br>delivered if one was queued while reading was paused.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                |     |

_class_ asyncssh.SSHAcceptor [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/connection.html#SSHAcceptor) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHAcceptor "Link to this definition")

SSH acceptor

This class in a wrapper around an [`asyncio.Server`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/asyncio-eventloop.html#asyncio.Server "(in Python v3.13)") listener
which provides the ability to update the the set of SSH client or
server connection options associated with that listener. This is
accomplished by calling the [`update()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHAcceptor.update "asyncssh.SSHAcceptor.update") method, which takes the
same keyword arguments as the [`SSHClientConnectionOptions`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnectionOptions "asyncssh.SSHClientConnectionOptions")
and [`SSHServerConnectionOptions`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerConnectionOptions "asyncssh.SSHServerConnectionOptions") classes.

In addition, this class supports all of the methods supported by
[`asyncio.Server`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/asyncio-eventloop.html#asyncio.Server "(in Python v3.13)") to control accepting of new connections.

|                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           |     |
| --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | --- |
| get_addresses() [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/connection.html#SSHAcceptor.get_addresses) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHAcceptor.get_addresses "Link to this definition")<br>Return socket addresses being listened on<br>This method returns the socket addresses being listened on.<br>It returns tuples of the form returned by<br>`socket.getsockname()`. If the listener was created<br>using a hostname, the host’s resolved IPs will be returned.<br>If the requested listening port was `0`, the selected<br>listening ports will be returned.<br>Returns:<br>A list of socket addresses being listened on                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         |     |
| get_port() [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/connection.html#SSHAcceptor.get_port) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHAcceptor.get_port "Link to this definition")<br>Return the port number being listened on<br>This method returns the port number being listened on.<br>If it is listening on multiple sockets with different port<br>numbers, this function will return `0`. In that case,<br>[`get_addresses()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHAcceptor.get_addresses "asyncssh.SSHAcceptor.get_addresses") can be used to retrieve the full<br>list of listening addresses and ports.<br>Returns:<br>The port number being listened on, if there’s only one                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                |     |
| close() [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/connection.html#SSHAcceptor.close) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHAcceptor.close "Link to this definition")<br>Stop listening for new connections<br>This method can be called to stop listening for new<br>SSH connections. Existing connections will remain open.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  |     |
| _async_ wait_closed() [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/connection.html#SSHAcceptor.wait_closed) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHAcceptor.wait_closed "Link to this definition")<br>Wait for this listener to close<br>This method is a coroutine which waits for this<br>listener to be closed.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                |     |
| update( _\*\*kwargs_) [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/connection.html#SSHAcceptor.update) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHAcceptor.update "Link to this definition")<br>Update options on an SSH listener<br>Acceptors started by [`listen()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.listen "asyncssh.listen") support options defined<br>in [`SSHServerConnectionOptions`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerConnectionOptions "asyncssh.SSHServerConnectionOptions"). Acceptors started<br>by [`listen_reverse()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.listen_reverse "asyncssh.listen_reverse") support options defined in<br>[`SSHClientConnectionOptions`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnectionOptions "asyncssh.SSHClientConnectionOptions").<br>Changes apply only to SSH client/server connections accepted<br>after the change is made. Previously accepted connections<br>will continue to use the options set when they were accepted. |     |

If `n` is not provided or<br>set to `-1`, it reads until EOF or a signal is received.<br>If EOF is received and the receive buffer is empty, an<br>empty [`bytes`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#bytes "(in Python v3.13)") or [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") object is returned.<br>If the next data in the stream is a signal, the signal is<br>delivered as a raised exception.<br>Note<br>Unlike traditional [`asyncio`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/asyncio.html#module-asyncio "(in Python v3.13)") stream readers,<br>the data will be delivered as either [`bytes`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#bytes "(in Python v3.13)") or<br>a [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") depending on whether an encoding was<br>specified when the underlying channel was opened.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   |     |

If EOF is received and the receive buffer<br>is empty, an empty [`bytes`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#bytes "(in Python v3.13)") or [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") object is returned.<br>If the next data in the stream is a signal, the signal is<br>delivered as a raised exception.<br>Note<br>In Python 3.5 and later, [`SSHReader`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHReader "asyncssh.SSHReader") objects<br>can also be used as async iterators, returning input<br>data one line at a time.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            |     |
| _async_ readuntil( _separator_, _max_separator_len=0_) [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/stream.html#SSHReader.readuntil) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHReader.readuntil "Link to this definition")<br>Read data from the stream until `separator` is seen<br>This method is a coroutine which reads from the stream until<br>the requested separator is seen. If a match is found, the<br>returned data will include the separator at the end.<br>The `separator` argument can be a single [`bytes`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#bytes "(in Python v3.13)") or [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")<br>value, a sequence of multiple [`bytes`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#bytes "(in Python v3.13)") or [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") values,<br>or a compiled regex ( [`re.Pattern`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/re.html#re.Pattern "(in Python v3.13)")) to match against,<br>returning data as soon as a matching separator is found<br>in the stream.<br>When passing a regex pattern as the separator, the<br>`max_separator_len` argument should be set to the<br>maximum length of an expected separator match. This<br>can greatly improve performance, by minimizing how far<br>back into the stream must be searched for a match.<br>When passing literal separators to match against, the<br>max separator length will be set automatically.<br>Note<br>For best results, a separator regex should<br>both begin and end with data which is as<br>unique as possible, and should not start or<br>end with optional or repeated elements.<br>Otherwise, you run the risk of failing to<br>match parts of a separator when it is split<br>across multiple reads.<br>If EOF or a signal is received before a match occurs, an<br>[`IncompleteReadError`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/asyncio-exceptions.html#asyncio.IncompleteReadError "(in Python v3.13)")<br>is raised and its `partial` attribute will contain the<br>data in the stream prior to the EOF or signal.<br>If the next data in the stream is a signal, the signal is<br>delivered as a raised exception. |     |

| _async_ get( _remotepaths_, _localpath=None_, _\*_, _preserve=False_, _recurse=False_, _follow_symlinks=False_, _sparse=True_, _block_size=-1_, _max_requests=-1_, _progress_handler=None_, _error_handler=None_) [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/sftp.html#SFTPClient.get) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SFTPClient.get "Link to this definition")<br>Download remote files<br>This method downloads one or more files or directories from<br>the remote system. Either a single remote path or a sequence<br>of remote paths to download can be provided.<br>When downloading a single file or directory, the local path can<br>be either the full path to download data into or the path to an<br>existing directory where the data should be placed. In the<br>latter case, the base file name from the remote path will be<br>used as the local name.<br>When downloading multiple files, the local path must refer to<br>an existing directory.<br>If no local path is provided, the file is downloaded<br>into the current local working directory.<br>If preserve is [`True`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True "(in Python v3.13)"), the access and modification times<br>and permissions of the original file are set on the<br>downloaded file.<br>If recurse is [`True`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True "(in Python v3.13)") and the remote path points at a<br>directory, the entire subtree under that directory is<br>downloaded.<br>If follow_symlinks is set to [`True`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True "(in Python v3.13)"), symbolic links found<br>on the remote system will have the contents of their target<br>downloaded rather than creating a local symbolic link. When<br>using this option during a recursive download, one needs to<br>watch out for links that result in loops.<br>The block_size argument specifies the size of read and write<br>requests issued when downloading the files, defaulting to<br>the maximum allowed by the server, or 16 KB if the server<br>doesn’t advertise limits.<br>The max_requests argument specifies the maximum number of<br>parallel read or write requests issued, defaulting to a<br>value between 16 and 128 depending on the selected block<br>size to avoid excessive memory usage.<br>If progress_handler is specified, it will be called after<br>each block of a file is successfully downloaded. The arguments<br>passed to this handler will be the source path, destination<br>path, bytes downloaded so far, and total bytes in the file<br>being downloaded. If multiple source paths are provided or<br>recurse is set to [`True`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True "(in Python v3.13)"), the progress_handler will be<br>called consecutively on each file being downloaded.<br>If error_handler is specified and an error occurs during<br>the download, this handler will be called with the exception<br>instead of it being raised. This is intended to primarily be<br>used when multiple remote paths are provided or when recurse<br>is set to [`True`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True "(in Python v3.13)"), to allow error information to be collected<br>without aborting the download of the remaining files. The<br>error handler can raise an exception if it wants the download<br>to completely stop. Otherwise, after an error, the download<br>will continue starting with the next file.<br>Parameters:<br>- **remotepaths** ( [`PurePath`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/pathlib.html#pathlib.PurePath "(in Python v3.13)"), [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)"), or [`bytes`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#bytes "(in Python v3.13)"),<br> or a sequence of these) – The paths of the remote files or directories to download<br> <br>- **localpath** ( [`PurePath`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/pathlib.html#pathlib.PurePath "(in Python v3.13)"), [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)"), or [`bytes`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#bytes "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> The path of the local file or directory to download into<br> <br>- **preserve** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> Whether or not to preserve the original file attributes<br> <br>- **recurse** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> Whether or not to recursively copy directories<br> <br>- **follow_symlinks** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> Whether or not to follow symbolic links<br> <br>- **sparse** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> Whether or not to do a sparse file copy where it is supported<br> <br>- **block_size** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> The block size to use for file reads and writes<br> <br>- **max_requests** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> The maximum number of parallel read or write requests<br> <br>- **progress_handler** ( [`callable`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#callable "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> The function to call to report download progress<br> <br>- **error_handler** ( [`callable`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#callable "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> The function to call when an error occurs<br> <br>Raises:<br>[`OSError`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/exceptions.html#OSError "(in Python v3.13)") if a local file I/O error occurs<br>[`SFTPError`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SFTPError "asyncssh.SFTPError") if the server returns an error Either a single local path or a sequence of<br>local paths to upload can be provided.<br>When uploading a single file or directory, the remote path can<br>be either the full path to upload data into or the path to an<br>existing directory where the data should be placed. In the<br>latter case, the base file name from the local path will be<br>used as the remote name.<br>When uploading multiple files, the remote path must refer to<br>an existing directory.<br>If no remote path is provided, the file is uploaded into the<br>current remote working directory.<br>If preserve is [`True`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True "(in Python v3.13)"), the access and modification times<br>and permissions of the original file are set on the<br>uploaded file.<br>If recurse is [`True`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True "(in Python v3.13)") and the local path points at a<br>directory, the entire subtree under that directory is<br>uploaded.<br>If follow_symlinks is set to [`True`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True "(in Python v3.13)"), symbolic links found<br>on the local system will have the contents of their target<br>uploaded rather than creating a remote symbolic link. When<br>using this option during a recursive upload, one needs to<br>watch out for links that result in loops.<br>The block_size argument specifies the size of read and write<br>requests issued when uploading the files, defaulting to<br>the maximum allowed by the server, or 16 KB if the server<br>doesn’t advertise limits.<br>The max_requests argument specifies the maximum number of<br>parallel read or write requests issued, defaulting to a<br>value between 16 and 128 depending on the selected block<br>size to avoid excessive memory usage.<br>If progress_handler is specified, it will be called after<br>each block of a file is successfully uploaded. The arguments<br>passed to this handler will be the source path, destination<br>path, bytes uploaded so far, and total bytes in the file<br>being uploaded. If multiple source paths are provided or<br>recurse is set to [`True`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True "(in Python v3.13)"), the progress_handler will be<br>called consecutively on each file being uploaded.<br>If error_handler is specified and an error occurs during<br>the upload, this handler will be called with the exception<br>instead of it being raised. This is intended to primarily be<br>used when multiple local paths are provided or when recurse<br>is set to [`True`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True "(in Python v3.13)"), to allow error information to be collected<br>without aborting the upload of the remaining files. The<br>error handler can raise an exception if it wants the upload<br>to completely stop. Otherwise, after an error, the upload<br>will continue starting with the next file.<br>Parameters:<br>- **localpaths** ( [`PurePath`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/pathlib.html#pathlib.PurePath | open( _path_, _mode='r'_, _attrs=SFTPAttrs()_, _encoding='utf-8'_, _errors='strict'_, _block_size=SFTP_BLOCK_SIZE_, _max_requests=\_MAX_SFTP_REQUESTS_) [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/sftp.html#SFTPClient.open) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SFTPClient.open "Link to this definition")

Open a remote file

This method opens a remote file and returns an
[`SFTPClientFile`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SFTPClientFile "asyncssh.SFTPClientFile") object which can be used to read and
write data and get and set file attributes.

The path can be either a [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") or [`bytes`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#bytes "(in Python v3.13)") value. If it is a
str, it will be encoded using the file encoding specified
when the [`SFTPClient`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SFTPClient "asyncssh.SFTPClient") was started.

The following open mode flags are supported:

> | Mode       | Description                                                                                                  |
> | ---------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ |
> | FXF_READ   | Open the file for reading.                                                                                   |
> | FXF_WRITE  | Open the file for writing. If both this and FXF_READ<br>are set, open the file for both reading and writing. |
> | FXF_APPEND | Force writes to append data to the end of the file<br>regardless of seek position.                           |
> | FXF_CREAT  | Create the file if it doesn’t exist. Without this,<br>attempts to open a non-existent file will fail.        |
> | FXF_TRUNC  | Truncate the file to zero length if it already exists.                                                       |
> | FXF_EXCL   | Return an error when trying to open a file which<br>already exists.                                          |

Instead of these flags, a Python open mode string can also be
provided. Python open modes map to the above flags as follows:

> | Mode | Flags                                            |
> | ---- | ------------------------------------------------ |
> | r    | FXF_READ                                         |
> | w    | FXF_WRITE \| FXF_CREAT \| FXF_TRUNC              |
> | a    | FXF_WRITE \| FXF_CREAT \| FXF_APPEND             |
> | x    | FXF_WRITE \| FXF_CREAT \| FXF_EXCL               |
> | r+   | FXF_READ \| FXF_WRITE                            |
> | w+   | FXF_READ \| FXF_WRITE \| FXF_CREAT \| FXF_TRUNC  |
> | a+   | FXF_READ \| FXF_WRITE \| FXF_CREAT \| FXF_APPEND |
> | x+   | FXF_READ \| FXF_WRITE \| FXF_CREAT \| FXF_EXCL   |

Including a ‘b’ in the mode causes the `encoding` to be set
to [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)"), forcing all data to be read and written as bytes
in binary format.

Most applications should be able to use this method regardless
of the version of the SFTP protocol negotiated with the SFTP
server. A conversion from the pflags_or_mode values to the
SFTPv5/v6 flag values will happen automatically. However, if
an application wishes to set flags only available in SFTPv5/v6,
the [`open56()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SFTPClient.open56 "asyncssh.SFTPClient.open56") method may be used to specify these flags
explicitly.

The attrs argument is used to set initial attributes of the
file if it needs to be created. Otherwise, this argument is
ignored.

The block_size argument specifies the size of parallel read and
write requests issued on the file. If set to [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)"), each read
or write call will become a single request to the SFTP server.
Otherwise, read or write calls larger than this size will be
turned into parallel requests to the server of the requested
size, defaulting to the maximum allowed by the server, or 16 KB
if the server doesn’t advertise limits.

> Note
>
> The OpenSSH SFTP server will close the connection
> if it receives a message larger than 256 KB. So,
> when connecting to an OpenSSH SFTP server, it is
> recommended that the block_size be left at its
> default of using the server-advertised limits.

The max_requests argument specifies the maximum number of
parallel read or write requests issued, defaulting to a
value between 16 and 128 depending on the selected block
size to avoid excessive memory usage.

Parameters:

- **path** ( [`PurePath`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/pathlib.html#pathlib.PurePath "(in Python v3.13)"), [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)"), or [`bytes`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#bytes "(in Python v3.13)")) – The name of the remote file to open

- **pflags_or_mode** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)") or [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  The access mode to use for the remote file (see above)

- **attrs** ( [`SFTPAttrs`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SFTPAttrs "asyncssh.SFTPAttrs")) – (optional)
  File attributes to use if the file needs to be created

- **encoding** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  The Unicode encoding to use for data read and written
  to the remote file

- **errors** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  The error-handling mode if an invalid Unicode byte
  sequence is detected, defaulting to ‘strict’ which
  raises an exception

- **block_size** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)") or [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  The block size to use for read and write requests

- **max_requests** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  The maximum number of parallel read or write requests

Returns:

An [`SFTPClientFile`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SFTPClientFile "asyncssh.SFTPClientFile") to use to access the file

Raises:

[`SFTPError`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SFTPError "asyncssh.SFTPError") if the server returns an error | |

Most applications can continue to use [`open()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SFTPClient.open "asyncssh.SFTPClient.open")<br>even when talking to an SFTPv5/v6 server and the translation of<br>the flags will happen automatically. However, if an application<br>wishes to set flags only available in SFTPv5/v6, this method<br>provides that capability.<br>The following desired_access flags can be specified:<br>> ACE4_READ_DATA<br>> <br>> ACE4_WRITE_DATA<br>> <br>> ACE4_APPEND_DATA<br>> <br>> ACE4_READ_ATTRIBUTES<br>> <br>> ACE4_WRITE_ATTRIBUTES<br>The following flags can be specified:<br>> FXF_CREATE_NEW<br>> <br>> FXF_CREATE_TRUNCATE<br>> <br>> FXF_OPEN_EXISTING<br>> <br>> FXF_OPEN_OR_CREATE<br>> <br>> FXF_TRUNCATE_EXISTING<br>> <br>> FXF_APPEND_DATA<br>> <br>> FXF_APPEND_DATA_ATOMIC<br>> <br>> FXF_BLOCK_READ<br>> <br>> FXF_BLOCK_WRITE<br>> <br>> FXF_BLOCK_DELETE<br>> <br>> FXF_BLOCK_ADVISORY (SFTPv6)<br>> <br>> FXF_NOFOLLOW (SFTPv6)<br>> <br>> FXF_DELETE_ON_CLOSE (SFTPv6)<br>> <br>> FXF_ACCESS_AUDIT_ALARM_INFO (SFTPv6)<br>> <br>> FXF_ACCESS_BACKUP (SFTPv6)<br>> <br>> FXF_BACKUP_STREAM (SFTPv6)<br>> <br>> FXF_OVERRIDE_OWNER (SFTPv6)<br>At this time, FXF_TEXT_MODE is not supported. Also, servers<br>may support only a subset of these flags. For example,<br>the AsyncSSH SFTP server doesn’t currently support ACLs,<br>file locking, or most of the SFTPv6 open flags, but<br>support for some of these may be added over time.<br>Parameters:<br>- **path** ( [`PurePath`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/pathlib.html#pathlib.PurePath "(in Python v3.13)"), [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)"), or **encoding** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> The Unicode encoding to use for data read and written<br> to the remote file<br> <br>- **errors** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> The error-handling mode if an invalid Unicode byte<br> sequence is detected, defaulting to ‘strict’ which<br> raises an exception<br> <br>- **block_size** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)") or | _async_ glob( _patterns_, _error_handler=None_) [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/sftp.html#SFTPClient.glob) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SFTPClient.glob "Link to this definition")<br>Match remote files against glob patterns<br>This method matches remote files against one or more glob<br>patterns. Either a single pattern or a sequence of patterns<br>can be provided to match against.<br>Supported wildcard characters include ‘\*’, ‘?’, and<br>character ranges in square brackets. In addition, ‘\*\*’<br>can be used to trigger a recursive directory search at<br>that point in the pattern, and a trailing slash can be<br>used to request that only directories get returned.<br>If error_handler is specified and an error occurs during<br>the match, this handler will be called with the exception<br>instead of it being raised. This is intended to primarily be<br>used when multiple patterns are provided to allow error<br>information to be collected without aborting the match<br>against the remaining patterns. The error handler can raise<br>an exception if it wants to completely abort the match.<br>Otherwise, after an error, the match will continue starting<br>with the next pattern.<br>An error will be raised if any of the patterns completely<br>fail to match, and this can either stop the match against<br>the remaining patterns or be handled by the error_handler<br>just like other errors.<br>Parameters:<br>- **patterns** ( [`PurePath`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/pathlib.html#pathlib.PurePath "(in Python v3.13)"), [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)"), or [`bytes`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#bytes "(in Python v3.13)"),<br> or a sequence of these) – Glob patterns to try and match remote files against<br> <br>- **error_handler** ( [`callable`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#callable "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> The function to call when an error occurs<br> <br>Raises:<br>[`SFTPError`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SFTPError "asyncssh.SFTPError") if the server returns an error<br>or no match is found |     |

_class_ asyncssh.SFTPClientFile [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/sftp.html#SFTPClientFile) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SFTPClientFile "Link to this definition")

SFTP client remote file object

This class represents an open file on a remote SFTP server. It
is opened with the [`open()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SFTPClient.open "asyncssh.SFTPClient.open") method on the
[`SFTPClient`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SFTPClient "asyncssh.SFTPClient") class and provides methods to read and write
data and get and set attributes on the open file.

--------------------------------------------------------------- | _async_ read( _size=-1_, _offset=None_) [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/sftp.html#SFTPClientFile.read) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SFTPClientFile.read "Link to this definition")<br>Read data from the remote file<br>This method reads and returns up to `size` bytes of data<br>from the remote file. If size is negative, all data up to<br>the end of the file is returned.<br>If offset is specified, the read will be performed starting<br>at that offset rather than the current file position. This<br>argument should be provided if you want to issue parallel<br>reads on the same file, since the file position is not<br>predictable in that case.<br>Data will be returned as a string if an encoding was set when<br>the file was opened. Otherwise, data is returned as bytes.<br>An empty [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") or [`bytes`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#bytes "(in Python v3.13)") object is returned when at EOF.<br>Parameters:<br>- **size** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – The number of bytes to read<br> <br>- **offset** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> The offset from the beginning of the file to begin reading<br> <br>Returns:<br>data read from the file, as a [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") or [`bytes`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#bytes "(in Python v3.13)")<br>Raises:<br>[`ValueError`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/exceptions.html#ValueError "(in Python v3.13)") if the file has been closed<br>[`UnicodeDecodeError`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/exceptions.html#UnicodeDecodeError "(in Python v3.13)") if the data can’t be<br>decoded using the requested encoding<br>[`SFTPError`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SFTPError "asyncssh.SFTPError") if the server returns an error     |     |
| _async_ read_parallel( _size=-1_, _offset=None_) [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/sftp.html#SFTPClientFile.read_parallel) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SFTPClientFile.read_parallel "Link to this definition")<br>Read parallel blocks of data from the remote file<br>This method reads and returns up to `size` bytes of data<br>from the remote file. If size is negative, all data up to<br>the end of the file is returned.<br>If offset is specified, the read will be performed starting<br>at that offset rather than the current file position.<br>Data is returned as a series of tuples delivered by an<br>async iterator, where each tuple contains an offset and<br>data bytes. Encoding is ignored here, since multi-byte<br>characters may be split across block boundaries.<br>To maximize performance, multiple reads are issued in<br>parallel, and data blocks may be returned out of order.<br>The size of the blocks and the maximum number of<br>outstanding read requests can be controlled using<br>the `block_size` and `max_requests` arguments passed<br>in the call to the [`open()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SFTPClient.open "asyncssh.SFTPClient.open")<br>method on the [`SFTPClient`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SFTPClient "asyncssh.SFTPClient") class.<br>Parameters:<br>- **size** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – The number of bytes to read<br> <br>- **offset** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> The offset from the beginning of the file to begin reading<br> <br>Returns:<br>an async iterator of tuples of offset and data bytes<br>Raises:<br>[`ValueError`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/exceptions.html#ValueError "(in Python v3.13)") if the file has been closed<br>[`SFTPError`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SFTPError "asyncssh.SFTPError") if the server returns an error |     |
| _async_ write( _data_, _offset=None_) [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/sftp.html#SFTPClientFile.write) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SFTPClientFile.write "Link to this definition")<br>Write data to the remote file<br>This method writes the specified data at the current<br>position in the remote file.<br>Parameters:<br>- **data** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") or [`bytes`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#bytes "(in Python v3.13)")) – The data to write to the file<br> <br>- **offset** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> The offset from the beginning of the file to begin writing<br> <br>If offset is specified, the write will be performed starting<br>at that offset rather than the current file position. _class_ asyncssh.SFTPServer( _chan_, _chroot=None_) [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/sftp.html#SFTPServer) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SFTPServer "Link to this definition")

SFTP server

Applications should subclass this when implementing an SFTP
server. The methods listed below should be implemented to
provide the desired application behavior.

> Note
>
> Any method can optionally be defined as a
> coroutine if that method needs to perform
> blocking operations to determine its result.

The `chan` object provided here is the [`SSHServerChannel`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerChannel "asyncssh.SSHServerChannel")
instance this SFTP server is associated with. It can be queried to
determine which user the client authenticated as, environment
variables set on the channel when it was opened, and key and
certificate options or permissions associated with this session.

> Note
>
> In AsyncSSH 1.x, this first argument was an
> [`SSHServerConnection`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerConnection "asyncssh.SSHServerConnection"), not an
> [`SSHServerChannel`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerChannel "asyncssh.SSHServerChannel"). When moving to AsyncSSH
> 2.x, subclasses of [`SFTPServer`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SFTPServer "asyncssh.SFTPServer") which
> implement an \_\_init\_\_ method will need to be
> updated to account for this change, and pass this
> through to the parent.

If the `chroot` argument is specified when this object is
created, the default [`map_path()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SFTPServer.map_path "asyncssh.SFTPServer.map_path") and [`reverse_map_path()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SFTPServer.reverse_map_path "asyncssh.SFTPServer.reverse_map_path")
methods will enforce a virtual root directory starting in that
location, limiting access to only files within that directory
tree. This will also affect path names returned by the
[`realpath()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SFTPServer.realpath "asyncssh.SFTPServer.realpath") and [`readlink()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SFTPServer.readlink "asyncssh.SFTPServer.readlink") methods.

By<br>default, it hides the portion of the local path associated<br>with the virtual “chroot” if one was specified.<br>Parameters:<br>**path** ( [`bytes`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#bytes "(in Python v3.13)")) – The local path name to reverse map<br>Returns:<br>bytes containing the path name to report to the client                                                                                                                                             |     |

| open( _path_, _pflags_, _attrs_) [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/sftp.html#SFTPServer.open) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SFTPServer.open "Link to this definition")

Open a file to serve to a remote client

This method returns a file object which can be used to read
and write data and get and set file attributes.

The possible open mode flags and their meanings are:

> | Mode       | Description                                                                                                  |
> | ---------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ |
> | FXF_READ   | Open the file for reading. If neither FXF_READ nor<br>FXF_WRITE are set, this is the default.                |
> | FXF_WRITE  | Open the file for writing. If both this and FXF_READ<br>are set, open the file for both reading and writing. |
> | FXF_APPEND | Force writes to append data to the end of the file<br>regardless of seek position.                           |
> | FXF_CREAT  | Create the file if it doesn’t exist. Without this,<br>attempts to open a non-existent file will fail.        |
> | FXF_TRUNC  | Truncate the file to zero length if it already exists.                                                       |
> | FXF_EXCL   | Return an error when trying to open a file which<br>already exists.                                          |

The attrs argument is used to set initial attributes of the
file if it needs to be created. Otherwise, this argument is
ignored.

Parameters:

- **path** ( [`bytes`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#bytes "(in Python v3.13)")) – The name of the file to open

- **pflags** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – The access mode to use for the file (see above)

- **attrs** ( [`SFTPAttrs`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SFTPAttrs "asyncssh.SFTPAttrs")) – File attributes to use if the file needs to be created

Returns:

A file object to use to access the file

Raises:

[`SFTPError`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SFTPError "asyncssh.SFTPError") to return an error to the client | |
| open56( _path_, _desired_access_, _flags_, _attrs_) [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/sftp.html#SFTPServer.open56) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SFTPServer.open56 "Link to this definition")

Open a file to serve to a remote client (SFTPv5 and later)

This method returns a file object which can be used to read
and write data and get and set file attributes.

Supported desired_access bits include `ACE4_READ_DATA`,
`ACE4_WRITE_DATA`, `ACE4_APPEND_DATA`, `ACE4_READ_ATTRIBUTES`,
and `ACE4_WRITE_ATTRIBUTES`.

Supported disposition bits in flags and their meanings are:

> | Disposition           | Description                                      |
> | --------------------- | ------------------------------------------------ |
> | FXF_OPEN_EXISTING     | Open an existing file                            |
> | FXF_OPEN_OR_CREATE    | Open an existing file or create a new one        |
> | FXF_CREATE_NEW        | Create a new file                                |
> | FXF_CREATE_TRUNCATE   | Create a new file or truncate an existing<br>one |
> | FXF_TRUNCATE_EXISTING | Truncate an existing file                        |

Other supported flag bits are:

> | Flag            | Description                               |
> | --------------- | ----------------------------------------- |
> | FXF_APPEND_DATA | Append data writes to the end of the file |

The attrs argument is used to set initial attributes of the
file if it needs to be created. Otherwise, this argument is
ignored.

Parameters:

- **path** ( [`bytes`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#bytes "(in Python v3.13)")) – The name of the file to open

- **desired_access** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – The access mode to use for the file (see above)

- **flags** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – The access flags to use for the file (see above)

- **attrs** ( [`SFTPAttrs`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SFTPAttrs "asyncssh.SFTPAttrs")) – File attributes to use if the file needs to be created

Returns:

A file object to use to access the file

Raises:

[`SFTPError`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SFTPError "asyncssh.SFTPError") to return an error to the client | |

_class_ asyncssh.SFTPAttrs [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/sftp.html#SFTPAttrs) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SFTPAttrs "Link to this definition")

SFTP file attributes

SFTPAttrs is a simple record class with the following fields:

> | Field        | Description                                    | Type   |
> | ------------ | ---------------------------------------------- | ------ |
> | type         | File type (SFTPv4+)                            | byte   |
> | size         | File size in bytes                             | uint64 |
> | alloc_size   | Allocation file size in bytes (SFTPv6+)        | uint64 |
> | uid          | User id of file owner                          | uint32 |
> | gid          | Group id of file owner                         | uint32 |
> | owner        | User name of file owner (SFTPv4+)              | string |
> | group        | Group name of file owner (SFTPv4+)             | string |
> | permissions  | Bit mask of POSIX file permissions             | uint32 |
> | atime        | Last access time, UNIX epoch seconds           | uint64 |
> | atime_ns     | Last access time, nanoseconds (SFTPv4+)        | uint32 |
> | crtime       | Creation time, UNIX epoch seconds (SFTPv4+)    | uint64 |
> | crtime_ns    | Creation time, nanoseconds (SFTPv4+)           | uint32 |
> | mtime        | Last modify time, UNIX epoch seconds           | uint64 |
> | mtime_ns     | Last modify time, nanoseconds (SFTPv4+)        | uint32 |
> | ctime        | Last change time, UNIX epoch seconds (SFTPv6+) | uint64 |
> | ctime_ns     | Last change time, nanoseconds (SFTPv6+)        | uint32 |
> | acl          | Access control list for file (SFTPv4+)         | bytes  |
> | attrib_bits  | Attribute bits set for file (SFTPv5+)          | uint32 |
> | attrib_valid | Valid attribute bits for file (SFTPv5+)        | uint32 |
> | text_hint    | Text/binary hint for file (SFTPv6+)            | byte   |
> | mime_type    | MIME type for file (SFTPv6+)                   | string |
> | nlink        | Link count for file (SFTPv6+)                  | uint32 |
> | untrans_name | Untranslated name for file (SFTPv6+)           | bytes  |

Extended attributes can also be added via a field named
`extended` which is a list of bytes name/value pairs.

When setting attributes using an [`SFTPAttrs`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SFTPAttrs "asyncssh.SFTPAttrs"), only fields
which have been initialized will be changed on the selected file.

_class_ asyncssh.SFTPVFSAttrs [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/sftp.html#SFTPVFSAttrs) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SFTPVFSAttrs "Link to this definition")

SFTP file system attributes

SFTPVFSAttrs is a simple record class with the following fields:

> | Field   | Description                              | Type   |
> | ------- | ---------------------------------------- | ------ |
> | bsize   | File system block size (I/O size)        | uint64 |
> | frsize  | Fundamental block size (allocation size) | uint64 |
> | blocks  | Total data blocks (in frsize units)      | uint64 |
> | bfree   | Free data blocks                         | uint64 |
> | bavail  | Available data blocks (for non-root)     | uint64 |
> | files   | Total file inodes                        | uint64 |
> | ffree   | Free file inodes                         | uint64 |
> | favail  | Available file inodes (for non-root)     | uint64 |
> | fsid    | File system id                           | uint64 |
> | flags   | File system flags (read-only, no-setuid) | uint64 |
> | namemax | Maximum filename length                  | uint64 |

_class_ asyncssh.SFTPName [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/sftp.html#SFTPName) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SFTPName "Link to this definition")

SFTP file name and attributes

SFTPName is a simple record class with the following fields:

> | Field    | Description                       | Type                                                                                                                                                                     |
> | -------- | --------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ |
> | filename | Filename                          | [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") or [`bytes`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#bytes "(in Python v3.13)") |
> | longname | Expanded form of filename & attrs | [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") or [`bytes`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#bytes "(in Python v3.13)") |
> | attrs    | File attributes                   | [`SFTPAttrs`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SFTPAttrs "asyncssh.SFTPAttrs")                                                                |

A list of these is returned by [`readdir()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SFTPClient.readdir "asyncssh.SFTPClient.readdir")
in [`SFTPClient`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SFTPClient "asyncssh.SFTPClient") when retrieving the contents of a directory.

_class_ asyncssh.SFTPLimits [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/sftp.html#SFTPLimits) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SFTPLimits "Link to this definition")

SFTPLimits is a simple record class with the following fields:
