> | max_read_len     | Max allowed size of an SFTP read request  | uint64 |
> | max_write_len    | Max allowed size of an SFTP write request | uint64 |
> | max_open_handles | Max allowed number of open file handles   | uint64 |

## Public Key Support [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#public-key-support "Link to this heading")

AsyncSSH has extensive public key and certificate support.

Supported public key types include DSA, RSA, and ECDSA. In addition, Ed25519
and Ed448 keys are supported if OpenSSL 1.1.1b or later is installed.
Alternately, Ed25519 support is available when the libnacl package and
libsodium library are installed.

Supported certificate types include OpenSSH version 01 certificates for
DSA, RSA, ECDSA, Ed25519, and Ed448 keys and X.509 certificates for DSA,
RSA, and ECDSA keys.

Support is also available for the certificate critical options of
force-command and source-address and the extensions permit-X11-forwarding,
permit-agent-forwarding, permit-port-forwarding, and permit-pty in
OpenSSH certificates.

Several public key and certificate formats are supported including
PKCS#1 and PKCS#8 DER and PEM, OpenSSH, RFC4716, and X.509 DER and
PEM formats.

PEM and PKCS#8 password-based encryption of private keys is supported, as
is OpenSSH private key encryption when the bcrypt package is installed.

### Specifying private keys [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#specifying-private-keys "Link to this heading")

Private keys may be passed into AsyncSSH in a variety of forms. The
simplest option is to pass the name of a file to read one or more
private keys from.

An alternate form involves passing in a list of values which can be
either a reference to a private key or a tuple containing a reference
to a private key and a reference to a corresponding certificate or
certificate chain.

Key references can either be the name of a file to load a key from,
a byte string to import as a key, or an already loaded [`SSHKey`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHKey "asyncssh.SSHKey")
private key. See the function [`import_private_key()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.import_private_key "asyncssh.import_private_key") for the list
of supported private key formats.

Certificate references can be the name of a file to load a certificate
from, a byte string to import as a certificate, an already loaded
[`SSHCertificate`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHCertificate "asyncssh.SSHCertificate"), or `None` if no certificate should be
associated with the key.

Whenever a filename is provided to read the private key from, an attempt
is made to load a corresponding certificate or certificate chain from a
file constructed by appending ‘-cert.pub’ to the end of the name. X.509
certificates may also be provided in the same file as the private key,
when using DER or PEM format.

When using X.509 certificates, a list of certificates can also be
provided. These certificates should form a trust chain from a user or
host certificate up to some self-signed root certificate authority
which is trusted by the remote system.

Instead of passing tuples of keys and certificates or relying on file
naming conventions for certificates, you also have the option of
providing a list of keys and a separate list of certificates. In this
case, AsyncSSH will automatically match up the keys with their
associated certificates when they are present.

New private keys can be generated using the [`generate_private_key()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.generate_private_key "asyncssh.generate_private_key")
function. The resulting [`SSHKey`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHKey "asyncssh.SSHKey") objects have methods which can
then be used to export the generated keys in several formats for
consumption by other tools, as well as methods for generating new
OpenSSH or X.509 certificates.

### Specifying public keys [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#specifying-public-keys "Link to this heading")

Public keys may be passed into AsyncSSH in a variety of forms. The
simplest option is to pass the name of a file to read one or more
public keys from.

An alternate form involves passing in a list of values each of which
can be either the name of a file to load a key from, a byte string
to import it from, or an already loaded [`SSHKey`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHKey "asyncssh.SSHKey") public key.
See the function [`import_public_key()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.import_public_key "asyncssh.import_public_key") for the list of supported
public key formats.

### Specifying certificates [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#specifying-certificates "Link to this heading")

Certificates may be passed into AsyncSSH in a variety of forms. The
simplest option is to pass the name of a file to read one or more
certificates from.

An alternate form involves passing in a list of values each of which
can be either the name of a file to load a certificate from, a byte string
to import it from, or an already loaded [`SSHCertificate`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHCertificate "asyncssh.SSHCertificate") object.
See the function [`import_certificate()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.import_certificate "asyncssh.import_certificate") for the list of supported
certificate formats.

### Specifying X.509 subject names [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#specifying-x-509-subject-names "Link to this heading")

X.509 certificate subject names may be specified in place of public keys
or certificates in authorized_keys and known_hosts files, allowing any
X.509 certificate which matches that subject name to be considered a
known host or authorized key. The syntax supported for this is compatible
with PKIX-SSH, which adds X.509 certificate support to OpenSSH.

To specify a subject name pattern instead of a specific certificate,
base64-encoded certificate data should be replaced with the string
‘Subject:’ followed by a comma-separated list of X.509 relative
distinguished name components.

AsyncSSH extends the PKIX-SSH syntax to also support matching on a
prefix of a subject name. To indicate this, a partial subject name
can be specified which ends in ‘,\*’. Any subject which matches the
relative distinguished names listed before the “,\*” will be treated
as a match, even if the certificate provided has additional relative
distinguished names following what was matched.

### Specifying X.509 purposes [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#specifying-x-509-purposes "Link to this heading")

When performing X.509 certificate authentication, AsyncSSH can be
passed in an allowed set of ExtendedKeyUsage purposes. Purposes are
matched in X.509 certificates as OID values, but AsyncSSH also allows
the following well-known purpose values to be specified by name:

| Name              | OID                |
| ----------------- | ------------------ |
| serverAuth        | 1.3.6.1.5.5.7.3.1  |
| clientAuth        | 1.3.6.1.5.5.7.3.2  |
| secureShellClient | 1.3.6.1.5.5.7.3.20 |
| secureShellServer | 1.3.6.1.5.5.7.3.21 |

Values not in the list above can be specified directly by OID as a
dotted numeric string value. Either a single value or a list of values
can be provided.

The check succeeds if any of the specified values are present in the
certificate’s ExtendedKeyUsage. It will also succeed if the certificate
does not contain an ExtendedKeyUsage or if the ExtendedKeyUsage contains
the OID 2.5.29.37.0, which indicates the certificate can be used for any
purpose.

This check defaults to requiring a purpose of ‘secureShellCient’ for
client certificates and ‘secureShellServer’ for server certificates
and should not normally need to be changed. However, certificates which
contain other purposes can be supported by providing alternate values to
match against, or by passing in the purpose ‘any’ to disable this checking.

### Specifying time values [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#specifying-time-values "Link to this heading")

When generating certificates, an optional validity interval can be
specified using the `valid_after` and `valid_before` parameters
to the [`generate_user_certificate()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHKey.generate_user_certificate "asyncssh.SSHKey.generate_user_certificate")
and [`generate_host_certificate()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHKey.generate_host_certificate "asyncssh.SSHKey.generate_host_certificate")
methods. These values can be specified in any of the following ways:

> - An int or float UNIX epoch time, such as what is returned by
>   [`time.time()`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/time.html#time.time "(in Python v3.13)").
>
> - A [`datetime.datetime`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/datetime.html#datetime.datetime "(in Python v3.13)") value.
>
> - A string value of `now` to request the current time.
>
> - A string value in the form `YYYYMMDD` to specify an absolute date.
>
> - A string value in the form `YYYYMMDDHHMMSS` to specify an
>   absolute date and time.
>
> - A time interval described in [Specifying time intervals](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#specifyingtimeintervals) which is
>   interpreted as a relative time from now. This value can be negative
>   to refer to times in the past or positive to refer to times in the
>   future.

| export_private_key( _format_name='openssh'_, _passphrase=None_, _cipher_name='aes256-cbc'_, _hash_name='sha256'_, _pbe_version=2_, _rounds=128_, _ignore_few_rounds=False_) [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/public_key.html#SSHKey.export_private_key) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHKey.export_private_key "Link to this definition")<br>Export a private key in the requested format<br>This method returns this object’s private key encoded in the<br>requested format. If a passphrase is specified, the key will<br>be exported in encrypted form.<br>Available formats include:<br>> pkcs1-der, pkcs1-pem, pkcs8-der, pkcs8-pem, openssh<br>By default, openssh format will be used.<br>Encryption is supported in pkcs1-pem, pkcs8-der, pkcs8-pem,<br>and openssh formats. For pkcs1-pem, only the cipher can be<br>specified. For pkcs8-der and pkcs-8, cipher, hash and PBE<br>version can be specified. For openssh, cipher and rounds<br>can be specified.<br>Available ciphers for pkcs1-pem are:<br>> aes128-cbc, aes192-cbc, aes256-cbc, des-cbc, des3-cbc<br>Available ciphers for pkcs8-der and pkcs8-pem are:<br>> aes128-cbc, aes192-cbc, aes256-cbc, blowfish-cbc,<br>> cast128-cbc, des-cbc, des2-cbc, des3-cbc, rc4-40, rc4-128<br>Available ciphers for openssh format include the following<br>[encryption algorithms](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#encryptionalgs).<br>Available hashes include:<br>> md5, sha1, sha256, sha384, sha512<br>Available PBE versions include 1 for PBES1 and 2 for PBES2.<br>Not all combinations of cipher, hash, and version are supported.<br>The default cipher is aes256. In the pkcs8 formats, the default<br>hash is sha256 and default version is PBES2.<br>In openssh format, the default number of rounds is 128.<br>Note<br>The openssh format uses bcrypt for encryption, but<br>unlike the traditional bcrypt cost factor used in<br>password hashing which scales logarithmically, the<br>encryption strength here scales linearly with the<br>rounds value. Since the cipher is rekeyed 64 times<br>per round, the default rounds value of 128 corresponds<br>to 8192 total iterations, which is the equivalent of<br>a bcrypt cost factor of 13.<br>Parameters:<br>- **format_name** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> The format to export the key in.<br> <br>- **passphrase** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") or [`bytes`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#bytes "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> A passphrase to encrypt the private key with.<br> <br>- **cipher_name** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> The cipher to use for private key encryption.<br> <br>- **hash_name** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> The hash to use for private key encryption.<br> <br>- **pbe_version** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> The PBE version to use for private key encryption.<br> <br>- **rounds** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)<br> The number of KDF rounds to apply to the passphrase.<br> <br>Returns:<br>[`bytes`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#bytes "(in Python v3.13)") representing the exported private key asyncssh.generate_private_key( _alg_name_, _comment=None_, _\*\*kwargs_) [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/public_key.html#generate_private_key) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.generate_private_key "Link to this definition")

Generate a new private key

This function generates a new private key of a type matching
the requested SSH algorithm. Depending on the algorithm, additional
parameters can be passed which affect the generated key.

Available algorithms include:

> ssh-dss, ssh-rsa, ecdsa-sha2-nistp256, ecdsa-sha2-nistp384,
> ecdsa-sha2-nistp521, ecdsa-sha2-1.3.132.0.10, ssh-ed25519,
> ssh-ed448, sk-ecdsa-sha2-nistp256@openssh.com,
> sk-ssh-ed25519@openssh.com

For dss keys, no parameters are supported. The key size is fixed at
1024 bits due to the use of SHA1 signatures.

For rsa keys, the key size can be specified using the `key_size`
parameter, and the RSA public exponent can be changed using the
`exponent` parameter. By default, generated keys are 2048 bits
with a public exponent of 65537.

For ecdsa keys, the curve to use is part of the SSH algorithm name
and that determines the key size. No other parameters are supported.

For ed25519 and ed448 keys, no parameters are supported. The key size
is fixed by the algorithms at 256 bits and 448 bits, respectively.

For sk keys, the application name to associate with the generated
key can be specified using the `application` parameter. It defaults
to `'ssh:'`. The user name to associate with the generated key can
be specified using the `user` parameter. It defaults to `'AsyncSSH'`.

When generating an sk key, a PIN can be provided via the `pin`
parameter if the security key requires it.

The `resident` parameter can be set to [`True`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True "(in Python v3.13)") to request that a
resident key be created on the security key. This allows the key
handle and public key information to later be retrieved so that
the generated key can be used without having to store any
information on the client system. It defaults to [`False`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#False "(in Python v3.13)").

You can enable or disable the security key touch requirement by
setting the `touch_required` parameter. It defaults to [`True`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True "(in Python v3.13)"),
requiring that the user confirm their presence by touching the
security key each time they use it to authenticate.

Parameters:

- **alg_name** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – The SSH algorithm name corresponding to the desired type of key.

- **comment** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)"), [`bytes`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#bytes "(in Python v3.13)"), or [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  A comment to associate with this key.

- **key_size** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  The key size in bits for RSA keys.

- **exponent** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  The public exponent for RSA keys.

- **application** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  The application name to associate with the generated SK key,
  defaulting to `'ssh:'`.

- **user** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  The user name to associate with the generated SK key, defaulting
  to `'AsyncSSH'`.

- **pin** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  The PIN to use to access the security key, defaulting to [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)").

- **resident** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  Whether or not to create a resident key on the security key,
  defaulting to [`False`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#False "(in Python v3.13)").

- **touch_required** ( [`bool`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  Whether or not to require the user to touch the security key
  when authenticating with it, defaulting to [`True`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True "(in Python v3.13)").

Returns:

An [`SSHKey`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHKey "asyncssh.SSHKey") private key

Raises:

[`KeyGenerationError`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.KeyGenerationError "asyncssh.KeyGenerationError") if the requested key parameters
are unsupported

asyncssh.import_private_key( _data_, _passphrase=None_, _unsafe_skip_rsa_key_validation=None_) [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/public_key.html#import_private_key) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.import_private_key "Link to this definition")

Import a private key

This function imports a private key encoded in PKCS#1 or PKCS#8 DER
or PEM format or OpenSSH format. Encrypted private keys can be
imported by specifying the passphrase needed to decrypt them.

Parameters:

- **data** ( [`bytes`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#bytes "(in Python v3.13)") or ASCII [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – The data to import.

- **passphrase** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") or [`bytes`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#bytes "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  The passphrase to use to decrypt the key.

- **unsafe_skip_rsa_key_validation** ( [_bool_](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool "(in Python v3.13)")) – (optional)
  Whether or not to skip key validation when loading RSA private
  keys, defaulting to performing these checks unless changed by
  calling [`set_default_skip_rsa_key_validation()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.set_default_skip_rsa_key_validation "asyncssh.set_default_skip_rsa_key_validation").

Returns:

An [`SSHKey`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHKey "asyncssh.SSHKey") private key

asyncssh.import_public_key( _data_) [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/public_key.html#import_public_key) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.import_public_key "Link to this definition")

Import a public key

This function imports a public key encoded in OpenSSH, RFC4716, or
PKCS#1 or PKCS#8 DER or PEM format.

Parameters:

**data** ( [`bytes`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#bytes "(in Python v3.13)") or ASCII [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – The data to import.

Returns:

An [`SSHKey`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHKey "asyncssh.SSHKey") public key

asyncssh.import_certificate( _data_) [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/public_key.html#import_certificate) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.import_certificate "Link to this definition")

Import a certificate

asyncssh.set_default_skip_rsa_key_validation( _skip_validation_) [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/rsa.html#set_default_skip_rsa_key_validation) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.set_default_skip_rsa_key_validation "Link to this definition")

Set whether to disable RSA key validation in OpenSSL

OpenSSL 3.x does additional validation when loading RSA keys
as an added security measure. However, the result is that
loading a key can take significantly longer than it did before.

If all your RSA keys are coming from a trusted source, you can
call this function with a value of [`True`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True "(in Python v3.13)") to default to skipping
these checks on RSA keys, reducing the cost back down to what it
was in earlier releases.

This can also be set on a case by case basis by using the new
`unsafe_skip_rsa_key_validation` argument on the functions used
to load keys. This will only affect loading keys of type RSA.

Note

The extra cost only applies to loading existing keys, and
not to generating new keys. Also, in cases where a key is
used repeatedly, it can be loaded once into an [`SSHKey`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHKey "asyncssh.SSHKey")
object and reused without having to pay the cost each time.
So, this call should not be needed in most applications.

If an application does need this, it is strongly
recommended that the `unsafe_skip_rsa_key_validation`
argument be used rather than using this function to
change the default behavior for all load operations.

## SSH Agent Support [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#ssh-agent-support "Link to this heading")

AsyncSSH supports the ability to use private keys managed by the OpenSSH
ssh-agent on UNIX systems. It can connect via a UNIX domain socket to
the agent and offload all private key operations to it, avoiding the need
to read these keys into AsyncSSH itself. An ssh-agent is automatically
used in [`create_connection()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.create_connection "asyncssh.create_connection") when a valid `SSH_AUTH_SOCK` is set
in the environment. An alternate path to the agent can be specified via
the `agent_path` argument to this function.

An ssh-agent can also be accessed directly from AsyncSSH by calling
[`connect_agent()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.connect_agent "asyncssh.connect_agent"). When successful, this function returns an
[`SSHAgentClient`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHAgentClient "asyncssh.SSHAgentClient") which can be used to get a list of available
keys, add and remove keys, and lock and unlock access to this agent.

SSH agent forwarding may be enabled when making outbound SSH connections
by specifying the `agent_forwarding` argument when calling
[`create_connection()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.create_connection "asyncssh.create_connection"), allowing processes running on the server
to tunnel requests back over the SSH connection to the client’s ssh-agent.

Agent forwarding can be enabled when starting an SSH server by
specifying the `agent_forwarding` argument when calling
[`create_server()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.create_server "asyncssh.create_server"). In this case, the client’s ssh-agent can be
accessed from the server by passing the [`SSHServerConnection`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerConnection "asyncssh.SSHServerConnection") as
the argument to [`connect_agent()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.connect_agent "asyncssh.connect_agent") instead of a local path. Alternately,
when an [`SSHServerChannel`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerChannel "asyncssh.SSHServerChannel") has been opened, the [`get_agent_path()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerChannel.get_agent_path "asyncssh.SSHServerChannel.get_agent_path") method may be called on it to get a
path to a UNIX domain socket which can be passed as the `SSH_AUTH_SOCK`
to local applications which need this access. Any requests sent to this
socket are forwarded over the SSH connection to the client’s ssh-agent.

asyncssh.connect_agent( _agent_path=''_) [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/agent.html#connect_agent) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.connect_agent "Link to this definition")

Make a connection to the SSH agent

This function attempts to connect to an ssh-agent process
listening on a UNIX domain socket at `agent_path`. If not
provided, it will attempt to get the path from the `SSH_AUTH_SOCK`
environment variable.

If the connection is successful, an [`SSHAgentClient`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHAgentClient "asyncssh.SSHAgentClient") object
is returned that has methods on it you can use to query the
ssh-agent. If no path is specified and the environment variable
is not set or the connection to the agent fails, an error is
raised.

Parameters:

**agent_path** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") or [`SSHServerConnection`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerConnection "asyncssh.SSHServerConnection")) – (optional)
The path to use to contact the ssh-agent process, or the
[`SSHServerConnection`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerConnection "asyncssh.SSHServerConnection") to forward the agent request
over.

Returns:

An [`SSHAgentClient`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHAgentClient "asyncssh.SSHAgentClient")

Raises:

[`OSError`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/exceptions.html#OSError "(in Python v3.13)") or [`ChannelOpenError`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.ChannelOpenError "asyncssh.ChannelOpenError") if the
connection to the agent can’t be opened

## Config File Support [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#config-file-support "Link to this heading")

AsyncSSH has partial support for parsing OpenSSH client and server
configuration files (documented in the “ssh_config” and “sshd_config”
UNIX man pages, respectively). Not all OpenSSH configuration options
are applicable, so unsupported options are simply ignored. See below
for the OpenSSH config options that AsyncSSH supports.

AsyncSSH also supports “Host” and “Match” conditional blocks. As with
the config options themselves, not all match criteria are supported,
but the supported criteria should function similar to OpenSSH.

AsyncSSH also supports the “Include” directive, to allow one config
file trigger the loading of others.

### Supported client config options [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#supported-client-config-options "Link to this heading")

The following OpenSSH client config options are currently supported:

> KbdInteractiveAuthentication

> PreferredAuthentications
>
> Port
>
> ProxyCommand
>

For the “Match” conditional, the following criteria are currently supported:

> All
>
> Canonical
>
> Exec
>
> Final
>
> Host
>
> LocalUser
>
> OriginalHost
>
> User
>
> Warning
>
> When instantiating [`SSHClientConnectionOptions`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnectionOptions "asyncssh.SSHClientConnectionOptions")
> objects manually within an asyncio task, you may block
> the event loop if the options refer to a config file with
> “Match Exec” directives which don’t return immediate
> results. In such cases, the asyncio `run_in_executor()`
> function should be used. This is taken care of automatically
> when options objects are created by AsyncSSH APIs such as
> [`connect()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.connect "asyncssh.connect") and [`listen()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.listen "asyncssh.listen").

Match criteria can be negated by prefixing the criteria name with ‘!’.
This will negate the criteria and causing the match block to be evaluated
only if the negated criteria all fail to match.

The following client config token expansions are currently supported:

| Token | Expansion                                                    |
| ----- | ------------------------------------------------------------ |
| %%    | Literal ‘%’                                                  |
| %C    | SHA-1 Hash of connection info (local host, host, port, user) |
| %d    | Local user’s home directory                                  |
| %h    | Remote host                                                  |
| %i    | Local uid (UNIX-only)                                        |
| %L    | Short local hostname (without the domain)                    |
| %l    | Local hostname (including the domain)                        |
| %n    | Original remote host                                         |
| %p    | Remote port                                                  |
| %r    | Remote username                                              |
| %u    | Local username                                               |

These expansions are available in the values of the following config options:

> CertificateFile
>
> IdentityAgent
>
> IdentityFile
>
> RemoteCommand

### Specifying byte counts [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#specifying-byte-counts "Link to this heading")

A byte count may be passed into AsyncSSH as an integer value, or as a
string made up of a mix of numbers followed by an optional letter of
‘k’, ‘m’, or ‘g’, indicating kilobytes, megabytes, or gigabytes,
respectively. Multiple of these values can be included. For instance,
‘2.5m’ means 2.5 megabytes. This could also be expressed as ‘2m512k’
or ‘2560k’.

### Specifying time intervals [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#specifying-time-intervals "Link to this heading")

A time interval may be passed into AsyncSSH as an integer or float value,
or as a string made up of a mix of positive or negative numbers and the
letters ‘w’, ‘d’, ‘h’, ‘m’, and ‘s’, indicating weeks, days, hours,
minutes, or seconds, respectively. Multiple of these values can be
included. For instance, ‘1w2d3h’ means 1 week, 2 days, and 3 hours.

## Known Hosts [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#known-hosts "Link to this heading")

AsyncSSH supports OpenSSH-style known_hosts files, including both
plain and hashed host entries. Regular and negated host patterns are
supported in plain entries. AsyncSSH also supports the `@cert_authority`
marker to indicate keys and certificates which should be trusted as
certificate authorities and the `@revoked` marker to indicate keys and
certificates which should be explicitly reported as no longer trusted.

### Specifying known hosts [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#specifying-known-hosts "Link to this heading")

Known hosts may be passed into AsyncSSH via the `known_hosts` argument
to [`create_connection()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.create_connection "asyncssh.create_connection"). This can be the name of a file or list of files
containing known hosts, a byte string containing data in known hosts format,
or an [`SSHKnownHosts`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHKnownHosts "asyncssh.SSHKnownHosts") object which was previously imported from a
string by calling [`import_known_hosts()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.import_known_hosts "asyncssh.import_known_hosts") or read from files by calling
[`read_known_hosts()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.read_known_hosts "asyncssh.read_known_hosts"). In all of these cases, the host patterns in the
list will be compared against the target host, address, and port being
connected to and the matching trusted host keys, trusted CA keys, revoked
keys, trusted X.509 certificates, revoked X.509 certificates, trusted
X.509 subject names, and revoked X.509 subject names will be returned.

Alternately, a function can be passed in as the `known_hosts` argument
that accepts a target host, address, and port and returns lists containing
trusted host keys, trusted CA keys, revoked keys, trusted X.509 certificates,
revoked X.509 certificates, trusted X.509 subject names, and revoked X.509
subject names.

If no matching is required and the caller already knows exactly what the
above values should be, these seven lists can also be provided directly in
the `known_hosts` argument.

See [Specifying public keys](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#specifyingpublickeys) for the allowed form of public key values
which can be provided, [Specifying certificates](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#specifyingcertificates) for the allowed form
of certificates, and [Specifying X.509 subject names](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#specifyingx509subjects) for the allowed form
of X.509 subject names.

asyncssh.match_known_hosts( _known_hosts_, _host_, _addr_, _port_) [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/known_hosts.html#match_known_hosts) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.match_known_hosts "Link to this definition")

Match a host, IP address, and port against a known_hosts list

This function looks up a host, IP address, and port in a list of
host patterns in OpenSSH `known_hosts` format and returns the
host keys, CA keys, and revoked keys which match.

The `known_hosts` argument can be any of the following:

> - a string containing the filename to load host patterns from
>
> - a byte string containing host pattern data to load
>
> - an already loaded [`SSHKnownHosts`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHKnownHosts "asyncssh.SSHKnownHosts") object containing
>   host patterns to match against
>
> - an alternate matching function which accepts a host, address,
>   and port and returns lists of trusted host keys, trusted CA
>   keys, and revoked keys to load
>
> - lists of trusted host keys, trusted CA keys, and revoked keys
>   to load without doing any matching

If the port is not the default port and no match is found
for it, the lookup is attempted again without a port number.

Parameters:

- **known_hosts** – The host patterns to match against

- **host** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – The hostname of the target host

- **addr** ( [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – The IP address of the target host

- **port** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – The port number on the target host, or [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)") for the default

Returns:

A tuple of matching host keys, CA keys, and revoked keys

## Authorized Keys [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#authorized-keys "Link to this heading")

AsyncSSH supports OpenSSH-style authorized_keys files, including the
cert-authority option to validate user certificates, enforcement of
from and principals options to restrict key matching, enforcement
of no-X11-forwarding, no-agent-forwarding, no-pty, no-port-forwarding,
and permitopen options, and support for command and environment options.

### Specifying authorized keys [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#specifying-authorized-keys "Link to this heading")

Authorized keys may be passed into AsyncSSH via the
`authorized_client_keys` argument to [`create_server()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.create_server "asyncssh.create_server") or by calling
[`set_authorized_keys()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerConnection.set_authorized_keys "asyncssh.SSHServerConnection.set_authorized_keys")
on the [`SSHServerConnection`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServerConnection "asyncssh.SSHServerConnection") from within the [`begin_auth()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServer.begin_auth "asyncssh.SSHServer.begin_auth") method in [`SSHServer`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHServer "asyncssh.SSHServer").

Authorized keys can be provided as either the name of a file or list of
files to read authorized keys from or an [`SSHAuthorizedKeys`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHAuthorizedKeys "asyncssh.SSHAuthorizedKeys") object
which was previously imported from a string by calling
[`import_authorized_keys()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.import_authorized_keys "asyncssh.import_authorized_keys") or read from files by calling
[`read_authorized_keys()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.read_authorized_keys "asyncssh.read_authorized_keys").

An authorized keys file may contain public keys or X.509 certificates
in OpenSSH format or X.509 certificate subject names. See
[Specifying X.509 subject names](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#specifyingx509subjects) for more information on using subject names
in place of specific X.509 certificates.

## Logging [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#logging "Link to this heading")

AsyncSSH supports logging through the standard Python [`logging`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/logging.html#module-logging "(in Python v3.13)") package.
Logging is done under the logger named `'asyncssh'` as well as a child
logger named `'asyncssh.sftp'` to allow different log levels to be set
for SFTP related log messages.

The base AsyncSSH log level can be set using the [`set_log_level()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.set_log_level "asyncssh.set_log_level")
function and the SFTP log level can be set using the [`set_sftp_log_level()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.set_sftp_log_level "asyncssh.set_sftp_log_level")
function. In addition, when either of these loggers is set to level DEBUG,
AsyncSSH provides fine-grained control over the level of debug logging
via the [`set_debug_level()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.set_debug_level "asyncssh.set_debug_level") function.

AsyncSSH also provides logger objects as members of connection, channel,
stream, and process objects that automatically log additional context about
the connection or channel the logger is a member of. These objects can
be used by application code to output custom log information associated
with a particular connection or channel. Logger objects are also provided
as members of SFTP client and server objects.

asyncssh.set_log_level( _level_) [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/logging.html#set_log_level) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.set_log_level "Link to this definition")

Set the AsyncSSH log level

This function sets the log level of the AsyncSSH logger. It
defaults to `'NOTSET`’, meaning that it will track the debug
level set on the root Python logger.

For additional control over the level of debug logging, see the
function [`set_debug_level()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.set_debug_level "asyncssh.set_debug_level") for additional information.

Parameters:

**level** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)") or [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – The log level to set, as defined by the [`logging`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/logging.html#module-logging "(in Python v3.13)") module

asyncssh.set_sftp_log_level( _level_) [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/logging.html#set_sftp_log_level) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.set_sftp_log_level "Link to this definition")

Set the AsyncSSH SFTP/SCP log level

This function sets the log level of the AsyncSSH SFTP/SCP logger.
It defaults to `'NOTSET`’, meaning that it will track the debug
level set on the main AsyncSSH logger.

For additional control over the level of debug logging, see the
function [`set_debug_level()`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.set_debug_level "asyncssh.set_debug_level") for additional information.

Parameters:

**level** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)") or [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)")) – The log level to set, as defined by the [`logging`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/logging.html#module-logging "(in Python v3.13)") module

asyncssh.set_debug_level( _level_) [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/logging.html#set_debug_level) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.set_debug_level "Link to this definition")

Set the AsyncSSH debug log level

This function sets the level of debugging logging done by the
AsyncSSH logger, from the following options:

> | Level | Description                          |
> | ----- | ------------------------------------ |
> | 1     | Minimal debug logging                |
> | 2     | Full debug logging                   |
> | 3     | Full debug logging with packet dumps |

The debug level defaults to level 1 (minimal debug logging).

Note

For this setting to have any effect, the effective log
level of the AsyncSSH logger must be set to DEBUG.

Warning

Extreme caution should be used when setting debug
level to 3, as this can expose user passwords in
clear text. This level should generally only be
needed when tracking down issues with malformed
or incomplete packets.

Parameters:

**level** ( [`int`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int "(in Python v3.13)")) – The debug level to set, as defined above.

SSH Process error

This exception is raised when an [`SSHClientProcess`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientProcess "asyncssh.SSHClientProcess") exits
with a non-zero exit status and error checking is enabled. In
addition to the usual error code, reason, and language, it
contains the following fields:

> | Field       | Description                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       | Type                                                                                                                                                                        |
> | ----------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
> | env         | The environment the client requested<br>to be set for the process                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 | [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") or [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)")     |
> | command     | The command the client requested the<br>process to execute (if any)                                                                                                                                                                                                                               | [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") or [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)")     |
> | subsystem   | The subsystem the client requested the<br>process to open (if any)                                                                                                                                                                                                                                | [`str`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str "(in Python v3.13)") or [`None`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None "(in Python v3.13)")     |

_exception_ asyncssh.TimeoutError( _env_, _command_, _subsystem_, _exit_status_, _exit_signal_, _returncode_, _stdout_, _stderr_, _reason=''_, _lang='en-US'_) [\[source\]](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/asyncssh/process.html#TimeoutError) [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.TimeoutError "Link to this definition")

SSH Process timeout error

This exception is raised when a timeout occurs when calling the
[`wait`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientProcess.wait "asyncssh.SSHClientProcess.wait") method on [`SSHClientProcess`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientProcess "asyncssh.SSHClientProcess")
or the [`run`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.run "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection.run") method on
[`SSHClientConnection`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.SSHClientConnection "asyncssh.SSHClientConnection"). It is a subclass of [`ProcessError`](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#asyncssh.ProcessError "asyncssh.ProcessError")
and contains all of the fields documented there, including any output
received on stdout and stderr prior to when the timeout occurred. It
is also a subclass of [`asyncio.TimeoutError`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/asyncio-exceptions.html#asyncio.TimeoutError "(in Python v3.13)"), for code that
might be expecting that.

## Supported Algorithms [¶](https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#supported-algorithms "Link to this heading")

Algorithms can be specified as either a list of exact algorithm names
or as a string of comma-separated algorithm names that may optionally
include wildcards. An ‘\*’ in a name matches zero or more characters and
a ‘?’ matches exactly one character.

When specifying algorithms as a string, it can also be prefixed with ‘^’
to insert the matching algorithms in front of the default algorithms of
that type, a ‘+’ to insert the matching algorithms after the default
algorithms, or a ‘-’ to return the default algorithms with the matching
algorithms removed.

GSS authentication support is only available when the gssapi package is
installed on UNIX or the pywin32 package is installed on Windows.

Curve25519 and Curve448 support is available when OpenSSL 1.1.1 or
later is installed. Alternately, Curve25519 is available when the
libnacl package and libsodium library are installed.

SNTRUP support is available when the Open Quantum Safe (liboqs)
dynamic library is installed.

> OPEN_CONNECT_FAILED

> OPEN_UNKNOWN_CHANNEL_TYPE

> OPEN_REQUEST_PTY_FAILED
>
